OTTAWA, 9th January, 1904

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Public School Inspector McKinnon, in his last report on the Whycocomagh school, recommends that the salary of Mr McLennan, the teacher, be increased. This is a large school and the Department has lately put up a first-class building and Mr McLennan, who has had charge of it for the last year, is doing well. His present salary is only $250.00, which is a very small sum and should, I think, be increased to at least $300.00. The teachers of Indian schools in Nova Scotia have lately lost the local Government aid. Of the ten schools in Nova Scotia, seven of the teachers already receive $300.00 from the Department, which is, I think, the lowest salary we should offer to any of your schools.

[Signature]

Martin Beaver
The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa

OTTAWA, 26th August, 1905

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant; and in reply I beg to say that your resignation of the position of teacher of the Whycocoragh Indian school is hereby accepted.

[Signature]

A.J. McLennan, Esq.
Inverness,
N.S.
Dear Sir,

Your letter has suddenly filled me with a flood of myself. Really I must be next to Mahomet, so great have doubts become. You say that if the man has appetite, "holds the necessary qualifications he may be appointed," to teach the Indians, nothing to draw his salary, namely $300 per annum. Are any other qualifications needed besides holding the good will of the responsible members for the district? If so please let me know what they are since you impose upon me the pains of finding out whether the man holds the necessary qualifications.

I remain in your greatness. On the other hand I find that there is an Indian agent above me in this county else I should be advising you from more serious resignation and not you me. Of course there is no good blood between me and our representative since I put him in the hole a few years ago. Anyway he is master of the administration in this County at least so he has his fling. May he prosper. He told a man that would not tell me a lie that when he asked for anything in Ottawa he had to get it. He would make them give it. Another man told me that a member of Parliament told him that our men took off his coat to the Member of Parliament for an order like that. And must over the appointment of Public Officers. A secret police being still doing indirectly.

In the present case you do more for me than in a former one if I am similar. Kindly you give me the new teacher's address. Surely the doctor's
nephew is not going to quit before finishing up
the summer quarter as the long holidays would
therefore go unpaid for, so the possibility of
his finishing this term gives us plenty time to
find out what you consider necessary
qualifications. You know my mind already,
All that is needed is the favour of our M.
I am glad that Mr. MacLennan is through.
One must be a conscientious worker to
keep up interest in such a school. For my
part I take little or no interest in the
work for I find myself dealt with so
harshly that I have no heart in trying to
improve things. I get no cooperation from
those who should stand by me. When I was
going to college I happened to pick up
as a prefect in the studies more than one
year. I found that I could not control the boys
so thought they should be controlled. Having
no other prefects, had to do the Vice-rector to
whose care discipline belonged. With his support
found everything moving smoothly but if he
took but little real interest in the matter I liked
out a miserable existence and discipline was
below par. When we got no support as with a
change of rectors we sometimes did we tried to
hobble through somehow. If our work suited them
we could do nothing better than suit them. If my
work suited for all well and good. I believe
can do more for the Indians, even handicapped
as I am, than almost any other person within easy
distance of them. Otherwise I should throw the agency
away high to those who are sorry I even got it.

[Signature]
Indian Agent

River Bourgeois, St. John, January 21, 1907

Sir,

Complaint having reached me about the Indian School at Whyosomagh, Newcomb, Co., and being within reasonable distance of it on the 10th inst., I decided to visit it and endeavour to ascertain the cause, if any, for grievance.

A year ago, almost to a day, I inspected the school for the first time, and while the teacher, Mr. Daniel J. Gillis, an entire stranger to me, did not impress me favourably at all, the few pupils in attendance—I think there were six—gave evidence that some one had taught them to read indifferently and write fairly well, besides the bare rudiments of arithmetic and geography. But I was not in a position to make comparisons with regard to the standing of the school then and at any previous period. When I inspected it again on the 10th inst., seven pupils were present, and a few tests of their attainments revealed the fact that no progress whatever had been made during the year. The teacher could not deny that such was the case, and said that irregular attendance, due to carelessness on the part of parents, was the cause. His statement was correct in a measure; but I am disposed to agree with the Indians of Whyosomagh who assert that it is almost, if not quite, useless to send their children to the school while it is conducted by the present incumbent. They assert further that it has retrograded under his management.

I am convinced that Mr. Gillis does not possess the qualities necessary for a successful teacher.
in any school, much less an Indian school. His expression is that of a person not well-balanced in mind; and he is evidently of a nervous, excitable temperament.

I am altogether of opinion that the salary paid him by the Department is money well spent to gain advantage, and in the interests of education among the Indians of Whycomagh, who are naturally rather intelligent. I feel that there should be a change of teacher. My personal opinion in the matter is only that of official duty; and I should like the Department to ascertain what the actual views are on this subject.

Your obedient servant,

A.J. Boyd
Indian Dept.

The Secretary,

Ottawa, 2nd July, 1909.

Sir,-

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your report on the Indian School at Whyccocomagh, Inverness Co., N.S., and in reply beg to state that in view of the unfavorable condition of affairs you found when there, the Department has decided that the services of Mr. Gillis, the Teacher, should be dispensed with, and you are hereby authorized to notify him that his engagement will not be renewed after the close of the current quarter.

You will also be good enough to take necessary steps to secure a duly qualified teacher for this school, so that it may be re-opened after the summer holidays. Any applications you may receive should be submitted to the Department for its approval, with certificates of qualification and character.

Your obedient servant,

J.D. McLean
Secretary.

A. J. Boyd, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
River Bourgeois, C.B.,
N.S.

To the Hon. Minister of the Interior, Ottawa, Ont.,

This is the time when teachers are applying for schools—i.e., the teachers in N. Scotland.

I have never noticed the names of any of the Whapmagoostui Indians as successful candidates at Prov. Examinations. Can this be due to defective training?

I am a Grade B Teacher with a Viva Voce, M. Sch. Diploma, & thought as the Govt. is spending lavishly on the Indians that a Normal School Graduate would be the proper person.

Might I ask how much do you pay teachers per annum? Please take my name down as a probable applicant and if I be chosen, I think I can teach the young Indians up to Grades IX. X. XI which is no doubt the wish of the Government.

Yours,

[Signature]

Aug 10th

In your last telegram you say you are going to await information from me before making further progress in the matter of accommodating the Indian teacher at Whyacoomegagh or this County.

Would you please let me know what are the complaints against Gibbs the present teacher & who is the complainant? If the charges against Gibbs are such as will necessitate his removal I certainly protest against engaging Mr. Murphy. I think, as the Superintendent of the County, it is my duty to consider myself a friend to all who wish to promote a just person as the parties who are evidently attempting to injure this family. I must also observe that I cannot see any good reason why indeed in this matter. However, I do not intend to be bullied aside that easily by pigmy politicians such as I am suspicious have to be getting their way & the suspicion has to be getting away. Mr. Gibbs must be engaged as teacher at Whyacoomegagh. Would you kindly give me your Mr. Clark's present address.

Sincerely yours,

M. C. Christie
Marjum, October 4th

Your last telegram states that the Department has decided upon the dismissal of Mr. Hill's teacher at Wheaconough & appointing a successor until full information can be received from me. I may say that in my opinion the remark very good worthy of the matter of appointing a successor to Mr. Hill & certainly must insist that any recommendation to fill the vacancy must be inspected. I have a very clear idea how why Mr. Hill was dismissed & determine effort was made to make a place for Miss Murphy. The question of what work she did & that without my knowledge is a pretty strong against her something shady was being done.

I know Mr. Hill's way will be an opinion that he is an intelligent schoolteacher well suited to that in the Indian School Wheaconough. However, I am writing that he be removed if there is cause. Therefore asks that Mr. Hill be Remove without delay who applied for his position on what ground. I may have his dismissal & on what grounds, I may have him removed from the position of teacher who can bring something to pay about the figures heads who are withholding.

Ottawa, August 9, 1909.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 1st and 4th inst., asking for information regarding the dismissal of Mr. Daniel J. Gillis, teacher of the Whycoomagh Indian school and the proposed appointment of Miss Margaret A. Murphy as his successor.

In reply I beg to say that Mr. Gillis' services were dispensed with on the strength of a report received from Mr. A.J. Boyd, Indian Superintendent for Nova Scotia, who stated that his inspection of this school revealed the fact that no progress whatever had been made during the year which intervened between his previous inspection and that he was disposed to agree with the Indians, who assert that it is almost, if not quite, useless to send their children to the school while it is conducted by the present incumbent. They say that it has retrograded under his management. Mr. Boyd further stated that he is convinced that Mr. Gillis does not possess the qualities necessary for a successful teacher of any school, much less an Indian school. He concludes by saying that he is altogether of opinion that the salary paid Mr. Gillis by the Department is money not spent to good advantage and in the interest of education.

A. V. Chisholm, Esq., M.P.,
Margaree Harbour,
N.S.
education among the Indians of Whyocomagh, who are naturally rather intelligent, and he feels that there should be a change of teacher.

In view of this report nothing remained for the Department to do but secure the services of another teacher and Mr. Boyd was instructed to obtain a properly qualified teacher at once, so that no delay might occur in reopening the school after the summer holidays. Mr. Boyd forwarded an application from Miss Margaret A. Murphy, of St. Peter's, N.S., accompanied by a certificate from Mr. J.T. MacNeil, Inspector of Schools, who stated that she was the holder of a certificate, Class C of the Province, with Normal training, who was known to him from childhood as a young lady of irreproachable moral character. The Inspector further stated that Miss Murphy had taught school under his supervision for several years past and always gave good satisfaction to her employers as well as to himself as Inspector and that he had great pleasure in recommending her to any Board of Trustees requiring the services of a teacher of her class.

Memorandum.

Mr. Oliver,

Re Whyccoomagh Indian School.

I beg to submit herewith a statement regarding the dismissal of Mr. Daniel J. Gillis, teacher of the Whyccoomagh Indian school and the proposed appointment of Miss Margaret A. Murphy as his successor.

Mr. A.J. Boyd, Indian Superintendent for Nova Scotia, reported on the 31st June, last, that, owing to complaints which had reached him about this school, he made a special visit, in order to ascertain the cause, if any, for grievance. He had inspected the school a year previous, and he states that, while the teacher, an entire stranger to him, did not impress him favourably, he was not then in a position to make a comparison with regard to the standing of the school, but on his second visit a
few tests of the pupils' attainments revealed the fact that no progress whatever had been made during the year, a condition which the teacher did not deny but claimed that irregular attendance due to carelessness of parents was the cause. Mr. Boyd admits that the teacher's statement was correct in a measure but that he was disposed to agree with the Indians of Whyccoomagh, who assert that it is almost, if not quite, useless to send their children to the school while it is conducted by the present incumbent. The Indians further assert that it has retrograded under Mr. Gillis' management.

Mr. Boyd says that he is convinced that Mr. Gillis does not possess the qualities necessary for a successful teacher in any school, much less an Indian school. His expression is that of a person not well-balanced in mind and he is evidently of a nervous, excitable temperament.

Mr. Boyd concludes his report by stating that he is altogether of opinion that the salary paid by the Department to Mr. Gillis is money not spent to good advantage and in the interests of education among the Indians of Whyccoomagh, who are naturally rather intelligent, and feels
feels that there should be a change of teacher.

In view of this report the only course open to the Department was to dispense with Mr. Gillis' services and secure another teacher, and Mr. Boyd was instructed to take the necessary steps to secure a qualified teacher for this school, so that it might be reopened after the summer holidays, applications received by him to be submitted to the Department for its approval, with certificates of qualification and character. (Instructions dated July 3).

On the 25th of that month Mr. Boyd forwarded an application from Miss Margaret A. Murphy, of St. Peters, N.S., accompanied by a certificate from Mr. Jp P. MacNeil, Inspector of schools for the district, who stated that she was the holder of a certificate, Class C of the Province, with Normal training, and known to him since childhood as a young lady of irreproachable moral character. He further said that Miss Murphy had taught school under his supervision for several years past and always gave good satisfaction to her employers as well as to himself as Inspector and that he had great pleasure in recommending her.
her to any Board of Trustees requiring the services of a teacher of her class.

The Department had decided to appoint Miss Murphy but, owing to Mr. Chisholm's protest, action was deferred.

With regard to Mr. Chisholm's claim to have the right to recommend a successor I may state for your information that it is not the practice of the Department to refer the appointment of teachers of Indian schools to Members of Parliament. The usual course was followed in this instance, and, had it not been for Mr. Chisholm's intervention, Miss Murphy would have received the appointment at the usual salary of $300.00 per annum, and the school would have been reopened on the 16th inst.

Dear Sir,

With regard to Education among the Indians of this Agency I have only this to say. Nothing your Department has done for the Indians under my care, in this line seems to have any other end than to please the representative for the locality and hence School keeping has generally been a farce, that has nevertheless provided a sitting down job at a lazy man's salary for some party, storm beater, cheater. This accursed political expediency is sapping the Vitality of our young Empire and in your policy with regard to the Indian schools you worship the totem on bended knee, at least in this locality.

If the Department has any confidence in me as its agent it ought to defer to my opinion in preference to any other until it became convinced by proper investigation that I was not capable to represent it, then I should be replaced. The Department knows well that it has no more conscientious employees than the Catholic clergyman. We work to please God. I have taken such interest in the Schools of this County that the Local Government appointed me to a special Commission to investigate their condition, report thereon and suggest reforms or improvements. Only last night a School Inspector of the mainland wrote me for my opinion on a matter affecting schools. In spite of everything I am to have no hand in training those poor Micmac children who are as dear to me as my heart's blood. Since I took this agency I can't say that much improvement was made.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your communication of March 31st which, although in reply to a request for special report for publication in the Annual Report, is a criticism of the official course with reference to Indian education within your Agency. You have entirely failed to recognize the improvements which have been made during the past year. Following a report made by you on the 16th of July 1907, the Department erected a commodious school building on the Malagawatch Reserve and has appointed a competent teacher at that point who appears to be taking a great interest in his pupils. Is it possible that you have not visited the Reserve and seen these improvements which were based on your own recommendation? The former teacher at Whycocowagh has also been replaced and a competent teacher has been engaged who has since the summer holidays largely increased the attendance and stimulated the interest of the Indians in educational matters.

You ask the question whether you are to have no hand in training these poor Mic-Mac children. If you stand aloof from the means employed to train them, the answer must be in the affirmative but if you take an active interest in these matters and assist the teachers with your advice and encouragement, there is no doubt that their efficiency will be materially increased.

Mr. Bedley,

In reply to your memorandum of yesterday's date in reference to the establishment of a night school at Whycocomagh I beg to say that a night school was conducted for 36 nights during the winter months of 1911. The attendance was fairly satisfactory, but a number of the Indians were advanced in years. While the average attendance was very fair, being 22 out of 28, this is accounted for by the fact that a number of the Indians were very regular, at the same time there were several who did not show by their attendance any great interest in the school.

No request was made for the establishment of the school last winter and when a number of the Indians made application last month, asking that a night school be established from January 1st to May 1st, 1913, the Department advised them that it did not consider that it would be of any great benefit to them. One of the reasons for taking this attitude is the fact that none but male members of the band are allowed to attend the school. If the
the women might be allowed to attend and obtain advantage from the instruction that might be given in hygiene or if practical lessons could be given them in some of the branches of domestic science, I think that the night school might be of benefit.

The Indians on this reserve have not in the past evidenced a proper interest in the work of the day school, although there is a good teacher in charge, and a number of the men who attended the night school were married men. I may say also that the teacher did not furnish reports regularly, as asked for, and the Department for that reason is not fully aware of the work that was accomplished during the season that the school was in operation. However, if it is the wish of the Department to conduct a night school the experiment might be tried again for three months on three evenings each week, the remuneration to be at the rate previously paid, viz.- 50 cents an hour.

Report of Inspector James MacKinnon on Whycocemagh School.

School inspected on November 25th, 1913

The chief drawback to the progress at the school is the irregularity of attendance. Next comes the lack of interest in the work on the part of both parents and children. Indeed the former condition is due in no small part to the latter. As already indicated there is scarcely any parental control over the children—that is to say it is scarcely ever exercised either in school or any other matters. Consequently, notwithstanding the earnest efforts of the teacher, I cannot report satisfactory progress. The sanitary conditions in the homes although considerably better than in former years afford room for great improvement. At school the teacher insists on the observance of the ordinary rules of sanitation but once beyond the jurisdiction of the teacher the children seem to forget. I am of the opinion that if the children are to make any material progress in education they must be separated from their parents and put into an institution where the teacher can have full control over them during the whole term. At any rate the present system is a failure as evidenced by the fact that to my knowledge none of the Indians' schools under my observation has produced within fifteen years a single scholar capable of writing an ordinary letter correctly or able to converse on ordinary topics in passably good English.
Ottawa, February 3, 1914.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of the 17th ultimo, I regret having to corroborate Mr. Inspector McKinnon's report, which, if he had known the facts, might have been qualified by the statement that Indian parents at Whycocomagh, as I am convinced, should be able to accomplish more than they are doing in providing their children with food and clothing.

It appears to me, as it must to you, that instead of becoming self sustaining, Whycocomagh Indians are getting to be more dependent on the Department for support; and I begin to believe that they would rather live by scheming than by honest labour. At any rate, there can be no doubt that the majority of them might be better off than they are, and as a proof of this statement, I may say that, when I visited Whycocomagh reserve a few days ago, I found Charles Tony, a young man 33 years of age with a wife and two children - all enjoying good health, in very destitute circumstances; while his neighbor, Noel Gould, with a wife and five children had full and plenty for his family. They have exactly the same opportunities, so far as I could discover, with an advantage in Tony's favour, because he has only four in family, whereas, Gould has seven.

There is no good reason why Tony should not be

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
be as well circumstanced, at least, as his neighbour, and I have an idea that he might be, if he were given to understand that he must either work or go hungry. There is plenty of employment in Cape Breton this year, perhaps not always at one's door, but certainly within reasonable distance, as Noel Gould's case shows.

However, there is no doubt also that several children on almost every reserve in Nova Scotia are unable to attend school in winter for want of shoes, stockings, and other articles of clothing - a condition of things for which they are in no wise responsible, and I am disposed to recommend in every case an expenditure for their benefit.

With regard to Whycocomagh reserve, I recommend an expenditure of $40.00 to provide shoes, etc. for children of school age in need. I would also recommend the usual midday lunch of biscuit and cheese for pupils of Whycocomagh school as an experiment.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 17th instant, making report relative to the children attending school on the Whycocemagh Reserve; and in reply I beg to say, with regard to their requirements in the way of clothing, that the Department is of opinion that it would be to the interest of the Indians generally if they were obliged to provide clothing for their children, under all ordinary circumstances, instead of relying upon the Department to come to their aid. I may say that in view of your recommendation that $40.00 be expended in the purchase of clothing for the most needy of the children the Department will allow expenditure to that amount for the purpose stated. This matter is left in your hands, but it is expected that you will, from this time on, endeavor, along practical lines, to make the Indians generally rely upon their own exertions to provide clothing and other necessaries for their families. As above intimated the Department agrees with you that such a course will result in benefit to the Indians.

With regard to the case of Chas. Toney there would seem to be no doubt that this man is under the impression that the Department will come to his rescue in granting relief whenever he is in need and that he is thereby relieved from the necessity of work. You should disabuse his mind of this idea. It is hoped that you have not been too lenient in the past in dealing with these cases of this nature.

Dear Mr. McKenzie -

I have your letter of the 21st instant, in reference to the salary of Mr. John Gillis, formerly teacher of the Whyeeconagh Indian School.

I have looked up the records and I find that Mr. Gillis had been paid for his services in full to the end of the school year, June 30th, last, and taught to the end of October. He will be paid that proportion of the annual salary which the number of days he taught bears to the total number of teaching days in the year, namely 200. We do not take the holidays into account in payment of our teachers.

If a teacher puts in the full year he gets the full year's salary; if he is engaged only a portion of the year he is paid for the actual time that he worked on a basis of 200 days to the year.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Whycocomagh Indian Day School, dated October 30, 1919. Original on 103167-6

GENERAL REMARKS.

I regret to have to say that the progress and general conditions in this school are far from satisfactory. The attendance is poor, the discipline weak and the hygienic conditions not up to the standard required. The unsatisfactory attendance and discipline are due chiefly to a lack of interest in education on the part of the parents and the failure of the truant officer to do his duty. There can be no progress without fairly good attendance and proper discipline. Although there has been school here continuously for many years, I am not aware that there is a single Indian on the reserve capable of writing a letter in fairly correct English or who is able to carry on a conversation on ordinary topics in passably good English. There surely must be something wrong with the administration of the Indian schools when conditions such as those described above persist. It appears to me that the matter of the education of the Indians has not yet been taken very seriously by anybody.

I would recommend that the truant officer and all others concerned with the educational administration be spurred on a little.

Sgd. James MacKinnen,
Inspector

Sir,

I have to request that you will visit the Whyccomagh Reserve at as early a date as your other duties will permit and inquire fully into educational matters there and report to the Department.

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his visit of inspection in December, last, states as follows: "I regret to have to say that the progress made and the general conditions found in this school were far from satisfactory. The attendance is poor, the discipline weak and the hygienic conditions not up to the standard required. The unsatisfactory attendance and the discipline are due chiefly to the failure of the truant officer to do his duty and a lack of interest in education on the part of the parents. There can be no progress without proper discipline and fairly good attendance. Although there has been school here continuously for many years, I am not aware that there is a single Indian on the reserve capable of writing a letter in fairly correct English, or who is able to carry on a conversation of any kind in passably good English. I think there must be something radically wrong with the administration of the Indian schools when conditions such as those described above persist. It would appear that the matter of the education of the Indians has not yet been taken very seriously by anybody. I would recommend that the truant officer and all others concerned with the educational administration be 'spurred on' a little."

In November, last, Mr. Agent McLennan, forwarded the resignation of Mrs. McNeil, the teacher, which she later withdrew in a personal letter to the Department, and she has been allowed to remain temporarily in charge until a suitable teacher to succeed her can be secured, and the Agent was informed accordingly.

The Department is advised that Mrs. McNeil receives no support in her work and that the truant officer neglects his duties and that the Indian parents are indifferent regarding education. It would appear that she is competent to teach the school and that the lack of success is due to causes outside her control. The janitor's duties are also not properly attended to, and the Department understands that there has been no proper heating facilities in the school, as the Indians removed the stove for the purpose of holding a dance and returned another stove in place of the one which they removed. The teacher has recently complained of the condition of the stove and in this regard you were written to on the 22nd instant.

The conditions on this reserve as regards educational matters, as reported by the Public School Inspector, are most unsatisfactory, and, at the time of your visit, you should inquire fully into all the conditions and complaints. You should also closely inquire into the duties performed by the truant officer and the janitor and, if they are not satisfactory, both should be discharged and competent persons engaged to replace them. You should instruct the Indian parents that it is expected that they will see that their children attend regularly, and in addition

A. J. Ross, Esq.,
Indian Superintendent,
River Bourgeois, N.S.
that the school building is not to be used for other than school purposes and for religious instruction, if required.

A full report from you regarding the conditions at this school and the work being performed by the teacher, truant officer and janitor, as well as any recommendations you desire to make in order to improve conditions, will be waited after your visit, which you should arrange to make to this reserve as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, I beg to report that I visited the Indian Day School at Whycocomagh Reserve on the 17th instant and found the teacher, Mrs. Annie McNeil, present, but no pupils in attendance - not one.

The school room was in excellent condition, being comfortably warm, with good ventilation, and clean as the proverbial new pin. It was quite evident that the janitor, Stephen Christmas, must be doing his duties effectively, as the teacher admitted.

I asked Mrs. McNeil if there was any special reason for the non-attendance of pupils on that favourable occasion - the weather being very fine - and she informed me that there was none which did not apply every day for some time past, namely, the refusal of the Indians to send their children to school for the purpose of discrediting the value of her services, with a view to her dismissal. She did not think that their attitude was at all justified, as she had always endeavoured to conscientiously discharge her duties as teacher.

I then interviewed some of the principal men of the Whycocomagh band about the situation, and they stated by way of complaint that they had several good reasons for keeping their children out of school, namely:

1. The teacher had developed an untidiness in her personal appearance, due to negligence of attire, which they considered objectionable, as giving children a poor example of cleanliness and neatness in dress - qualities that are expected to be cultivated and improved in school under the teacher's care and direction.

2. The teacher had been in the habit of insulting their children in school by actions of a grossly indecent character.

3. The teacher had otherwise acted improperly in the presence of her pupils, which was a cause of scandal to them.

With regard to the first statement, I regret to say that my personal observations rather tend to corroborate it; as to the others, I submit that the only way to determine whether there is any truth in them or not is by making formal inquiry under oath into the situation. But, at any rate, there is no doubt in my mind that Mrs. McNeil has outlived her usefulness as teacher of the Whycocomagh Indian Day School.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 24th ultimo furnishing a report, as requested, regarding educational matters on the Whycocomagh Reserve.

In reply I beg to say that, as the Indian parents refuse to send their children to school under the charge of the present teacher and also in view of the other reasons stated by you, the Department agrees with you that Mrs. McNeil has outlived her usefulness as teacher of the Whycocomagh Indian Bay School.

In a recent letter received from her she states that, owing to not having received the support which she thought she was entitled to from the Agent and yourself, she was withdrawing from this school, and it may be that she vacated the position at the end of the March quarter. If not, you may inform her that her services are no longer required, and, if it is impossible to obtain another teacher, the school will have to remain closed for the present. Mrs. McNeil should prepare and forward a return showing the attendance, days taught, etc., covering the period up to the time when she leaves the work, in order that payment of the salary due her can be made.

You might take this matter up with Mr. Agent McLennan with a view to obtaining the services of another teacher, and the Department will be pleased to be informed as to the date on which Mrs. McNeil gives up her duties.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo enclosing the March quarter return of the Whyecoomagh Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that Mrs. McNeil, the teacher, is being paid salary and bonus for the full quarter.

Mr. Inspector Boyd has recently furnished a report regarding the educational conditions on this reserve and he was informed that, if Mrs. McNeil had not given up the duties of teacher voluntarily, she should be advised that her services would be no longer required, as the Indians refuse to send their children while Mrs. McNeil remains as teacher. The Inspector was requested to take this matter up with you with a view to obtaining the services of another teacher.

As you were informed by official letter of January 19th, last, the outside amount that can be allowed for salary for a qualified teacher will be $600.00 per annum. It is hoped that you will be able to nominate a teacher for this school at an early date, and the name, qualifications and experience of the teacher secured by you should be forwarded for the approval of the Department. However, if it is impossible to obtain another teacher at the present time, the school will have to remain closed. You might consult Mr. Inspector Boyd in the matter.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the amount of salary paid you for the period you taught the Whycocomagh Indian Day School, during the quarter ended September 30th, last.

In reply I beg to say that, as you have resigned from the position of teacher at this school, such resignation to take effect from the 31st instant, the Department can only pay you a salary for the number of days you teach during the present school year, which began after the summer holidays. There are 200 teaching days in each school year. You were paid for 21 days in the September quarter, or, 21/200 of your yearly salary of $500.00.

Upon the receipt of a return, you will be paid for the number of days you teach during the present month. The salary of a teacher in the day schools is only paid by quarterly instalments in the case where the teacher remains during the full school year, namely, from September to the end of the following June.

Your obedient servant

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st inst. No. 108167-3 with reference to the amount of salary paid me for the quarter ending September 30th last.

In reply I beg to say that I am still of the opinion that I am entitled to the balance unpaid for the following reasons—Preparations for duty at the school here on Monday Oct. 4th 1910, Mr. Sept. Boyd was here at the time; and as the school building was in the hands of the Indians, and capable for repair, I could not open for teaching until the month of October. I have paid my first quarterly instalment in January 1910, receiving $427.50 being at the rate of $250.00 for the school year. I received three increases in salary, the last at the rate of $500.00 for the second year which was the June quarter in 1911. By the above you can readily see, that I completed seven years continuous service at the end of the September quarter of this year.

The amount of salary received by me for the school year was as follows: March quarter 1910, $125.00; March quarter 1911, $125.00; June quarter 1910, $125.00; September quarter 1910, $500.00; Total $427.50 leaving a balance unpaid of $72.50, which I think you will find, in view of the length of service from the beginning.

I do not wish to make a claim that I do not think that I am fairly entitled to, but I feel from the explanation I have given that you will take into consideration the position I have, having the school here hundreds of dollars more of them when done, and a good deal of it private means that I had to call on from time to time, to help out until such a point in the benefit of the Indians as all the separate people who occupy the same and will kindly be called upon for the information.

Yours obediently,

Sir, I beg to bring before you what I consider to be unfair treatment by the department. I was appointed teacher of the Mo-Mac School at Whyecoomagh N.S., in September 1909, my duties to begin Oct. 1st of that year at a salary of $350.00 per annum. I reported for duty on Monday Oct. 4th, found the school building in the hands of the carpenters and painters, for repairs and school did not open until Oct. 11th. The 18th day of January 1910 I received a cheque from the department for my first quarterly salary, for the sum of $62.50. My letter of appointment did not specify as to the number of teaching days in the school year nor the number of hours to be taught each day. I enquired of Mr. Capt. Boyd, and Rev. Agent Mr. Pearson and they both informed me that in the absence of regulations I was to follow the usage in the public schools, which I did. I received two increases in salary, and in 1911 I was granted the maximum amount namely $500.00 beginning with the April quarter of that year. In July 1911 I was paid $125.00. The school closed for the summer holidays July 12th and opened September 1st. On the close of the July quarter, namely Sept. 30th, I sent in my report and in Oct. I received my quarter by cheque $125.00. This continued up to September of the present year. I made my report as usual and also sent my resignation to the department the same to take effect Oct. 3rd. About the 18th of Oct. I received a cheque for $52.50, I did not think anything about it as I felt it was a mistake so I wrote
The Salary etc.

I wrote making inquiries. I received a reply from Mr. Stewart paying that inasmuch as I had resigned, I was only entitled to pay rent for the twenty-one days taught in September and rent for the July quarter as heretofore, that the school year closed with the beginning of the July quarter, that the school year was two hundred days which would make my salary at the rate of $2.50 per day, I wrote a reply stating that I had always understood that my salary was for the school year not a daily wage, and that since such as my services began in Oct. 1911 that I had completed seven years continuous service in Oct. 1916, and that therefore I was entitled to seven years salary. I never had any intimation heretofore that I was to be paid by the day I had always received the full amount of salary at the end of each quarter, and could not understand why an exception should be made. I received another reply from Mr. Stewart and from what I could glean from it his contention was that I was paid six years salary up to the July quarter of this year and that if I was paid a full there would not be any money left to pay any successor. Despairing of getting a satisfactory explanation or a settlement I turned the matter over to Mr. MacKenzie Esq., and he advised me to lay the matter before you personally and that he was writing you in the meantime.

I am yet convinced that the sum of $72.50 due me for the July quarter of 1916, as I had always received the full amount heretofore. I acted on the square with the department.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

With reference to the letter from Mr. J. A. Gillis, late teacher of the Whycocomagh Indian School, in regard to a balance of salary claimed by him for the September quarter last, I beg to say that, as Mr. Gillis has already been informed, he was paid for the actual time he taught during that quarter. The Indian day school regulations provide as follows:

"In computing salaries for broken periods, teachers will be paid in the proportion that the number of days they taught bears to the total number of teaching days in the year.

Salaries of teachers will be payable quarterly upon receipt of returns; but where a teacher is engaged to take charge of a school, duties to commence after the summer holidays, payment for the September quarter will be made as provided for in the case of broken periods in the previous paragraphs; and at the end of the year, or when services expire if before the end of a year, the necessary adjustment..."
adjustment will be made and all arrears, if any paid.

All teachers will be required to give at least one month's notice of their intention to resign."

When sending in his return for the September quarter, 1916, Mr. Gillis notified the Department of his intended resignation on the 31st proximo and upon receipt of a return showing the number of days he taught during the month of October a cheque will be sent for the amount due him.

There were 21 teaching days in that month and if he taught that number he is entitled to receive $52.50. This added to the amount he has already received would make $105.00, which would leave out of the $500.00 provided for the salary of the teacher of this school, $395.00. There would still be 158 teaching days in the year and it would take exactly this balance to pay his successor's salary for the balance of the year. If Mr. Gillis is paid anything more than he is entitled to it would make a shortage in the appropriation for this school.

Mr. Gillis is, however, correct in his statement that had he not given notice when sending in his September
he September quarter return him would have received his full quarter's salary, as he was an old teacher.

As no one has yet succeeded him, it is a question for the Department to decide whether they will allow Mr. Gillis anything further. He has had charge of this school for seven years and from reports received gave satisfaction.

[Signature]

Mr. Benson,

Mr. Scott is of opinion that we ought as a retiring solicitor allow Mr. Gillis the full salary for the third quarter. It should be pointed out that this is a matter of grace.

The Secretary Dept of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, Can.

Sir,

Received official cheques of your Department for service as teacher in the Indian Day School here for Sept quarter. The bonus cheque (No. 2351) Oct. 8th is in fifteen dollars. Now I taught twenty-one days and there was a public holiday, Sept. 5th Labor Day, besides making twenty-two days. Taking this rate I find that it takes twenty-two days to make up $150.00 the total bonus. I may be wrong but I thought the total was the authorized teaching days in the
School year was 200 days
The salary cheque was No. 1701
of same date is $52.50
Taking 200 days as the full term
bonus for 23 days should be $6.50
not $4.50; and the salary cheque
should be $55.00 not $52.50

So you see that if I am
right in taking 200 days
as the full term, I am short
between the two cheques, $4.00
that is if I am entitled to pay
for the holiday.

Please write soon and
explain how the cheque figures have
been found.

Yours very respectfully,
Angus W. Macdonald
Teacher
OTTAWA, October 19th, 1921.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 14th instant, regarding the salary and bonus paid you for the September quarter, last, as teacher of the Whycocomagh Indian Day School.

In reply I beg to say that you taught 21 days in that quarter, for which you were paid 21/200ths of your yearly salary of $500, or $52.50. You also received the bonus for one month. The bonus to teachers of Indian Day Schools, amounting to $150 per annum for the present fiscal year ending March 31st, next, is paid on a monthly basis for the ten teaching months, or $15.00 per month. A teacher, in order to draw the full yearly salary, is required to teach 200 days, and if you remain and teach this number of days to June 30th, next, the end of the school year, you will receive your full yearly salary.

A copy of the Indian Day School Regulations is enclosed herewith for your information.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Angus A. MacDonald, Esq.,
Teacher, Indian Day School,

Sir,

With further reference to your letter of the 1st inst., No. 103167-5A, I beg to report that I visited Whycecemagh, N.S., as soon after the receipt of your instructions as other official business engaging my attention at the time would permit; but in the absence of any plan or specifications, I could form no correct judgment of the merits of Mr. Chisholm's claim for extras.

Since my return from Whycecemagh, I received the original specifications, but no plan, from the agent, Revd. D. McPherson, Glendale, N.S.; and with these before me, after a personal interview with Mr. Chisholm, which I propose having seen, I hope to be able to furnish the Department with reliable information regarding this case.

With reference to the subject of your letter of the 26th July last, No.103167-5A, I beg to say that, until an opportunity should present itself for a personal interview with Mr. Alex. Chisholm, who was contractor for the erection of a school house on Whyccomagh Indian Reserve some ten years ago, it was not my intention to report with regard to his claims for extras. But having obtained from the present Agent, Revd. D. McPherson, the official specifications for the building, which I find considerably at variance with the views, implied or expressed, of Mr. Chisholm in the case, and having also looked into the matter while at Whyccomagh on a recent occasion, I desire now to state as follows:

1.- At the date the building was erected, the cost of finishing the interior with wood such as Mr. Chisholm furnished, would be about the same as if finished with plaster.

2 & 4.- The specifications do not mention particularly anything about paint; but they call for the erection of "a good, plain, substantial building, complete in every respect"; and, to my mind, a new building without paint would be very incomplete in one essential respect. Considering the conditions above quoted, I think it must have been well understood by Mr. Chisholm that painting the exterior of the building was part and parcel of his contract.

3.- I could not discover whether galvanized nails were used or not. If they were, it would make a difference of about $3.00 in the cost of construction.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Indian Department,
Ottawa.
5.- The double doors put in by the contractor were evidently of a cheap kind, but may have cost a couple of more dollars than if the two large single doors mentioned in the specifications had been furnished.

6.- Since my appointment as superintendent, I had what must have been Mr. Chisholm's Belfry taken down and rebuilt at a cost of about $8.00. Therefore, I cannot see how he could claim $40 extra for the original article; because the specifications called for a belfry at any rate, and I should say one was provided, which was not an improvement on that described in the specifications.

7.- If the cheque covering the final payment on Mr. Chisholm's contract was made payable to himself, I do not think he should look for anything more from the Department on that score. But if it was made payable to the late Agent, Father McIsaac, and he retained $20 of it until he should inspect the building, I think this claim is fairly defensible, and should be paid, providing Mr. Chisholm can satisfy the Department that he has never received the amount. I need not observe that Father McIsaac represented the Department, and any omission on his part cannot be chargeable to Mr. Chisholm.

The specifications called for plaster under the wainscoting. I do not think any was used, and that would be an advantage to the contractor.

Again, according to the specifications there were "4 iron ventilators to be placed in the outer walls; 2 on each side of the building". These ventilators seem to have been overlooked. There are none in the building; and this omission was also to the contractor's advantage.

In my opinion, Mr. Chisholm is entitled to nothing for extras.
extras; but, as already stated, I think that possibly he has a right to the $20, which he claims as the unpaid balance of his contract.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir:

In reply to your letter 53-2-5 of June 26th, 1930, wherein you state that the Public School Inspector has recommended certain repairs, improvements, etc., to the Teacher's residence and school grounds at Whycocomagh, in connection with this matter I beg to refer you to previous correspondence, my letter of April 19th, 1930 and your reply (53-2-8 of April 28th) wherein you authorized repairs for the roof of the Teacher's house.

In reference to the School Inspector's suggestion that the grounds about the school be improved, the land there is quite rocky and would have to be ploughed and several loads of earth hauled to complete the job. This would cost probably $125.00 and I think is too expensive for the funds available this year. Again, as work of this kind should be done in the early Summer months, there is a twofold reason why it should not be done this year. Sir,

May I ask please if the school-lunch, as given to the children of the Whycocomagh School during the past few years be authorized to start from October 1st. I have consulted both the Teacher and the Medical Doctor regarding this matter and they informed me that the lunch and cod liver-oil as supplied by the Dept. gave excellent results from every point of view. So many of the children are from tuberculous families and as the oil and lunch is given regular in school I consider it even better than if left to the parents to do so. The Teacher told me that many of the children did not like to take the oil and that he had received letters from their parents instructing him to discontinue giving it, but after he had forced them to take it in small doses at first, they soon were willing and anxious to take it.

Please send a supply of cod-liver-oil, and authorize the school lunch to commence on October 1st.

Your obedient servant,

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, regarding the serving of a lunch to the pupils of the Whycocomagh Indian Day School as from October 1st, next.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of you arranging for the purchase of milk from time to time. Last year, ten cents per quart was paid, but it is considered that it should be obtained at much less cost this year. You may also purchase the quantity of sugar, cheese and biscuits necessary. Approximately 30 pounds sugar, 70 pounds cheese and 120 pounds biscuits were supplied last year. The teacher should keep an accurate account of the milk supplied each month and hand same to you. You should then prepare a voucher, in triplicate, for the amount due, to which should be attached the statement of the teacher, which should also be certified by him. Our funds this year are extremely limited, and the Department will rely on you to see that all costs for the food for the lunch are kept to the lowest possible point. The teacher may start the serving of the lunch from October 1st, next, and continue same until the end of March, following.

Your letter states that sugar, biscuits and cocoa may be purchased for the serving of the lunch during the above mentioned dates and that milk may be served during December, January and February. As the cocoa cannot be prepared without milk, am I to understand that biscuits alone will be served during the months of November and March or that milk may be served as an additional part of the lunch during December, January and February? If biscuits and hot cocoa (prepared with milk) would be served during the whole authorized time, I do not consider that it would be necessary to serve additional milk at any time.

I am aware that the appropriation has been reduced and my reason for asking for this information is to assure that I will cause no error through misunderstanding of your authority, however I would recommend that the hot cocoa be served throughout the authorized time and that cannot be prepared without milk.

Schools and Teacher's Residence.

The wire fence surrounding the Indian Day School on Whycocomagh Reserve, N.S., requires some new posts and also to have the whole fence re-stretched. This fence was put up before I became Indian Agent and during my recent visit to Whycocomagh, I noted that the fence was down in places and the posts too rotten to hold the wire. Some of the posts are sound but many have fallen during the winter and new ones are required.

The fence surrounding the lot of the Teacher's Residence also requires a little repairing.

The barn on the Teacher's residence, Whycocomagh Reserve has two rotted sills and also some decayed woodwork and planks about the doors, windows etc. If this is not attended to as soon as possible, a greater amount of expense will be required to put the building in safe condition. It also requires painting but I would not suggest that this be done this year as the other repairs are more urgent.

Some repairs to the doors and door casings of the Indian Day School at Malagawatch Reserve are urgently required. The interior of this school also requires painting.

I would recommend that $60.00 be authorized for repairing the school fences and barn on Whycocomagh Reserve, and $8.00 for repairing the doors etc. on the Malagawatch School. If the Malagawatch school is to be repainted inside, about $40.00 will be required for material and labour. I would also say that all the above work be done by Indian labour as they can do it and so many are unemployed.

Dear Sir,

Mr. Alexander MacDonald, teacher of the Whyccocomagh Indian Day School, Whyccocomagh, N.S., has brought to my notice the fact that during last year's summer holidays, the windows of the school house were broken by vandals who assembled around the school grounds during the nights and while he was absent from the Reserve. The Teacher interviewed me regarding any action he may take to prevent a repetition of this destroying property this year and said that if material for shutters was furnished, he would make and install them free of charge, providing all concerned would be satisfied with his work.

My records show that the breaking of the said windows caused an expenditure of $5.30 last year and also that a few years previous, a less amount for a like purpose was incurred.

Seven shutters are required and I recommend that $1.50 each, a total of $10.50 be authorized for this purpose and that Mr. MacDonald make and install them free as he has offered. Planed lumber and hardware will be required and I feel sure that MacDonald can build the shutters satisfactory.

As the end of the school year is near, I would suggest that this expenditure be authorized as soon as possible so that the windows may be made secure when the holidays begin.

Yours truly,

A. G. Mac Neil

Rev. Sir:

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of an expenditure of approximately $10.50 in having shutters made and installed on the windows. It is noted that the teacher will make the shutters and install them free, if the material is supplied. You may, therefore, arrange for the purchase of the quantity of plain lumber and hardware required, obtaining accounts, in triplicate, which you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment.

I wish to refer to official letter of the 10th ultimo, regarding the repairs required to the wire fence around the school and also to the fence surrounding the lot of the teacher's residence. Please state the cost of the material and labour required in repairing these fences, when consideration will be given as to whether funds for the purpose can be provided or not.

You should also state the cost of the material required in repairing the barn near the teacher's residence. I would request that you state for what purpose this barn is used. Does the teacher keep any stock or carry out any farming operations? In any event, if he requires the barn, he should be responsible for carrying out any labour in making the repairs.

Rev. A. C. MacNeill,

June 26th, 1935.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir.—

With reference to your letter of the 22nd inst. I wish to state
that I visited Whycocomagh yesterday and inspected the fences surrounding
the school and Teacher's residence.

The wire of the fences is quite serviceable but many posts are decayed
and the wire requires re-stretching. I would estimate that an expenditure of
$18.00 for new posts, labour and the rental of a stretcher will put both
fences in good condition.

Regarding the barn, two sills are decayed and also parts of the windows,
doors and floor. However, if one sill was installed this Summer and the other
repairs made, the second sill would not be required for possibly a couple of
years, and the building would be in a condition so that it would not sink in
the ground or go out of shape. The barn is used to keep the Teacher's stock,
and also to house my own team when in Whycocomagh on Winter visits. It is
also used to store any Government implements or supplies which may be on
hand from time to time. The Teacher told me that he is quite willing to do
any work he can do in repairing the building but I know that the placing of
the sill requires an experienced man. I would estimate that an expenditure
of $30.00 for the purchase of material and the labour of an experienced
carpenter, with the Teacher giving all the help possible, would put the barn
in such a condition that it would be safe from further damage and in a fair
condition for many years.

Yours truly,

A. C. Mac Neil
Agent.
Ottawa, July 4, 1935.

Rev. Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th ultimo, giving an estimate of the cost of the repairs required to the fence surrounding the Whyccoomagh Indian Day School and also to the barn.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging to have the repairs required made to the fence. It is noted that a number of new posts will be required and that the wire should be re-stretched. The cost of the material and labour should be kept within your estimate, viz., $18.

The Department will approve of an expenditure not exceeding approximately the sum of $30 in supplying the materials and labour required in repairing the barn. It is noted that if one sill is installed and minor repairs made, the building would be placed in a condition that would be serviceable for a few years. It is noted that the teacher is willing to do as much of the work as possible. It is thought that Indian labour could be employed to assist him in making the repairs to the barn and also in repairing the fence.

You should obtain itemized accounts, in triplicate, covering the cost of all materials. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and forward for payment. You should also forward vouchers, in triplicate, properly certified, for the labour employed. It should be definitely stated the number of days or hours employed and the rate paid. It is expected that you will keep all costs in carrying out the work as low as possible.

I would request that you will have the work which has been authorized at this school carried out during the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Indian Agent

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL.

Whycocomagh Indian Day School (Inverness Co.).

Teacher: Mr. Alexander MacDonald.

This school building is in a fair state of repair. The seats in the school all need some repairs, tightening up, etc. One of the Indians there could do this work.

Mr. MacDonald informed me that he would do the work if the Department would supply the material, which we figured would cost about $40. I had a meeting with the Band at the school, and I noted at the meeting that the Indians certainly looked to Mr. MacDonald for guidance.

I trust the expenditure above referred to will be authorized.

Extract from Inspector Fraser's report on the Whydacomagh Day School dated March 9, 1936:

Stove should be jacketed with sheet-metal to facilitate even warmth and circulation of air.

Toilets need repairs and addition of doors.

The school should be repainted this year both inside and out. It is out of harmony with most of our schools in regard to colours used and moreover is in need of repainting.

The interior of the school is at present painted light blue. All, or almost all, our Inverness County schools are painted in about the following colour scheme:

Wainscot -- medium brown, or stained natural wood.
Walls -- very light buff.
Ceiling -- cream.

If your department insists on blue, then repainting in this colour should be done; but I recommend the colours described. Blue is a cold and depressing colour for classrooms, especially when unrelieved by any other colour.

The exterior of the school is in the worst possible colour for our beautiful landscape -- dull grey. The school should be painted in a combination of very light colours, probably straw trimmed with white or brown; buff with white; or white with green.

The playground is entirely without equipment. Two strong teeters and a three-swing outfit would be enjoyed and appreciated.

(Sgd.) D. C. Fraser

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,

Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

Yesterday, I received a telephone message from Mr. MacDonald, Teacher of the Whycocomagh Indian Day School, saying that, during a snow storm, parts of the school-house stove cracked open, they having been previously partly burnt out.

He made temporary repairs by which the stove can be safely used for a short time but as he strongly suggested new parts, I instructed Mr. J.K. MacDonald, Merchant of Whycocomagh to procure them as soon as possible.

The Teacher states that the rest of the stove was in good condition and that he would install the replacement parts himself, so to assure that there would be no case of fire, I gave the order without waiting for your authority or instructions, as the parts cannot be obtained locally and must be procured from Sackville, New Brunswick. The parts are; 1 fire pot and one top ring cover, which should cost only a few dollars.

Kindly let me have your authority for this expenditure which I, as well as the Teacher, considered very urgent.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Agent.
Ottawa,

Dear Sir:

I have already made application for the serving of the "hot lunch" in the Whyecoomagh Indian Day School. Pending a reply, I beg to ask for the articles listed on the requisition— if the request for the school lunch is to be granted. It begins November 15th.

May I once more call to your attention the fact that the interior of the school is badly in need of paint. A bright, cheerful room is a necessity in making the children health-conscious. A clean, cheerful atmosphere in the school—which is the Indian child's home for six hours daily—might influence a great deal his home life.

In the small amount of class-room decoration which I have already accomplished, I find the children very interested and willing helpers. I don't think I exaggerate the effects of a bright, homelike, comfortable class-room on these children.

Thanking you,

Ottawa,
November 21, 1941.

Reverend Sir:

In official letter of October 11 you were authorized to make the necessary arrangements for the serving of a midday lunch at the Malagawatch and Whycoomagh Schools for the period November 1, 1941, to April 30, 1942. We have recently received two accounts for supplies purchased for the month of November. The total amount for midday meal supplies charged in these two accounts is $56.08. From the vouchers it would appear that this amount was for the Whycoomagh School only. Is this correct or was this amount used at both schools? In either case it is a much larger amount than is usually supplied. It was never the intention that anything approaching a full meal should be served. It is our desire that a small quantity of food or hot drink should be served to supplement whatever the children may bring with them.

Yours truly,

Rev. A.C. MacNeil,
Indian Agent,
Glendale, N.S.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Herewith Mr. Morris' report on the Whycocomagh Agency, Oct 15- Oct. 26

SCHOOL - is an old building in very poor condition. The roof was leaking badly in many places. The agent was instructed to purchase the required number of rolls of ready-roofing and engage an Indian to put it on. This was the most economical repair that could be made - keeping in mind that the school will be abandoned in the next two or three years. Authority was also given to have the walls and ceiling washed. The toilets were in a dirty condition. The agent was instructed to have them attended to immediately.

Miss Mary MacKenzie, the teacher, appears to be a bright, intelligent person. Thirty-two children were in attendance. There were not enough desks to accommodate this number and it was necessary to have three children use one desk. Mr. MacKenzie is arranging to provide a few extra desks which he obtained from the Shubenacadie School. The children on the whole were clean and neat, and appeared to be well fed and well dressed.

TEACHER'S RESIDENCE - is a fairly good building, but as it has not been occupied for several years a great deal of damage has been done to it. There are many panes of glass broken. The back entrance has been damaged. Mr. William B. Young, Indian, who was the Postmaster at Whycocomagh, offered $100.00 for the teacher's residence (see Mr. Phelan's letter of October 16, File 53-2-d). Since Mr. Young made the offer he died suddenly on a potato picking trip to Maine. His family, however, are still interested in the purchase of the residence. I would strongly recommend that their offer be not accepted. If this Indian family purchased the building then they would not readily agree to move to Eskasoni when a new house would be available - possibly in the course of the next two years. Further, the fact that we would sell the building to an Indian might leave the impression that we do not intend to carry out the centralization scheme of the Cape Breton Indians completely. I would recommend that the residence be dismantled by a competent Indian carpenter on the reserve - the lumber, doors and windows, salvaged - and moved to Eskasoni by departmental truck. We are in urgent need of good seasoned finishing material. The cost of this work would, of course, be paid from Welfare funds. The agent should be advised to dismantle the building as recommended.
Ottawa, January 25, 1946.

P. B. Holman, Esq., Indian Agent, Eskasoni Chapel, CAPE BRETON, Nova Scotia,

Re: Teacher's Residence,
Eskasoni Reserve

You are instructed to have the teacher's residence on the Wyeconagh Reserve carefully dismantled, and salvage all material such as doors, door frames, window frames and sash, flooring, sheathing, bricks, etc. The material will then be trucked to the Eskasoni Reserve to be used in the construction of the store and residence to be built near the headquarters next summer. It is just possible that some of the salvaged material would not be suitable in the construction of the store - undoubtedly it could be used in the construction of Indian homes.

At the time of your visit to Ottawa you suggested that it might be wise not to dismantle the building during the winter time as the material might be stolen. It will be left to you to decide when the work should commence. The cost of the labour will be paid from Welfare Vote. If there are Indians on the Wyeconagh Reserve who are carpenters, and are trustworthy, then the work should be done by them - if not you have authority to use men from the Eskasoni Reserve.

J. E. Harris,
Welfare Division.

December 1, 1911.

The Chief Accountant,

A request has been made for a teacher's residence at the Whycocomagh reserve. Will you please let me have a memo. with regard to this.

D. S. G. I. A.
Ottawa, December 1, 1911.

Mr. Pedley,

It is not our practice to supply teacher's residences unless for some reason it is difficult to find board or residence within reasonable distance of the school. It should be possible to obtain a house in Whycocomagh village, which is not far from the reserve. Mr. Gillies, who is the school teacher there now, has taken a great interest in the Indians and his presence on the reserve I believe to have been beneficial. It was reported to me that he has rented an Indian house on the reserve. If it would serve the purpose of keeping him or some other good man on the reserve constantly I would feel inclined to recommend the putting up of a house sometime, at some future time.

[Signature]

C. A.
December 28, 1911.

Dear Sir,

With reference to your conversation here a short time ago, regarding the erection of a teacher's residence on the Whycocomagh Indian reserve, N. The Department is of opinion that it should be possible to obtain a house in Whycocomagh village, which is not very far from the reserve. At any rate, it is a matter that the Department will bear in mind, and, if found necessary, would incline towards a favourable view of the suggestion made.

Yours truly,

Sir,

I beg to advise you that a site has been selected by me for the teacher's residence to be erected on the Indian Reserve at Whycocomagh.

I have agreed to purchase from widow Mother Syllebay and her heirs a plot of ground, for that purpose, containing three acres. The price of the property, including water privileges, is one hundred dollars.

Sir,- I beg to call your attention to enclosed plan of first floor of teacher's residence at Whycocomagh, as at present laid out. There is a large room in the front that is practically useless as a bedroom, as it is open to the stairway, thereby having no privacy. If the partition wall marked (A) was extended to B with a door in the centre, and the door marked D placed at A then it would make two rooms and communicating. This would enable us to use the large room as a guest chamber. Light enough could be had from a window 20 x 20 placed about midway the stair and the light in the basement for the hall. The distance from A to B is fifteen feet with the ceiling eight feet high which makes 240 sq ft under plastering, Studwork and laths being also extra. Instead of a closet in the dining room there should be a door communicating with the living room so that a person could enter the dining room without going through the kitchen as at present. A large amount of extra space is wasted by not having a door in the wall back of the stairway. The place under the stairs could be used as a storeroom for trunks etc.

I talked the matter over with Mr. Poirier and he agrees to make the few changes required to secure the extra comfort for twenty-five dollars ($25).

I trust you will see fit to bring the above to the notice of the Department at an early day so that if allowed Mr. Poirier can get the extra material required.

Yours truly,

John A. Hillis

A.P. Boyd, Esq.,
Cameo,
Richmond Co.,
C.B.

MEMO.

Sir,

I enclose herewith a letter, which speaks for itself; and I quite agree with Mr. Gillis that the alterations he suggests are altogether desirable. The "guest chamber" he refers to is one that I should like to occupy myself occasionally. It would be useful for the Agent also.

The arrangement by which the dining room can be entered only by going through the kitchen is certainly objectionable and ought to be changed. There should be direct communication between the living room and the dining room; and I strongly recommend a change in the plan with that object in view.

Again, there is no provision in the plan for properly lighting the hall, which, I think, constitutes a serious defect. A narrow window over the front door will not give sufficient light, and, therefore, a "half-sash" should also be inserted in the wall of the house near the head of the stairs.

I hope the Department will consent to the alterations in the plan of the building, as suggested, especially as the cost of making them will involve only the small extra amount of $25, and the improvement will be worth more than the expenditure, in point of convenience and otherwise.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir, On page 10 "Specifications for teachers residence at Whynocomagh" there is a clause relating to how the windows should be adjusted, which to my mind is not very clear. One would be led to infer from reading the clause that it requires the upper parts to be hung with pack weights as is usually the case to permit of proper ventilation. The upper parts in the window as now adjusted are stationary, that is they are a strip of board about two inches wide, driven under the lower side of each, and extending to the window sill held in place with nails. Needless to say these will not be any means of lowering the upper part to get rid of the impure air in the rooms. Opening the lower part will permit the ingress of fresh air but that will only drive the hot and foul air in the rooms to the upper portion of the house a thing to try avoid that will make it very unhealthy. The only way to remedy this as the work is now so far advanced would be to use the Window holders such as is used on steam cars. It would be an easy matter to fit the brass ratchet pieces to the side of the frames and putting the thumb piece on the lower part of the sill. An arrangement like this on both sides would materially help the ventilation problem.

Yours obedient servant

John A. Gilling

Sir,

I beg to submit for your consideration the subject dealt with by Mr. Gillis, Indian teacher, Whycocomagh, N.S., in his letter to me of the 23rd inst., which I enclose herewith.

It is, no doubt, very important to have the proper ventilation of the teacher's residence in question attended to before the building is completed; and if Mr. Poirrier, the contractor, is undertaking to ignore the specifications in any particular, he should be checked at once by the person appointed to supervise the work of construction. I have not a copy of the specifications, and, therefore, am not in a position to know what they call for with regard to ventilation, but, at any rate, it would appear from what Mr. Gillis states that they are not at all explicit on that point.

As the building is nearing completion, it seems to me necessary to give this matter prompt attention, and I think the Department's decision in the case should be communicated directly to its building inspector at Whycocomagh.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir,

The Voucher herewith is for an expenditure authorized by me, without consulting the Department, under the following circumstances:

When I bargained with Mrs. Syllieboy for the lot of land, specified in the Voucher, it was stipulated that she should have her dwelling removed at her own expense; but so many people expressed to me the opinion that the bargain was a rather poor one for the old widow, considering the price paid for her place, that I decided to relieve her of the expense and make it a charge against the Department. Specification for Barn on Whycoomag Reserve

The location to be on the government road in connection with the teacher's residence at a place hereafter to be approved off.

The foundation to be eight stone piers built of flat stones laid in cement mixed in proportion of one barrel of cement to two barrels of sand, sand to be clear of cement, free from silt or clay properly pointed and to be of the following dimensions: Two feet by one foot and at least four feet high foundation for piers to be at least eighteen inches below the frost line.

Side walls to be 24 ft long 6 x 6, end piers to be 24 ft long 6 x 6 to be scarf jointed at corners and securely spiked with steel wire spikes six inches long at least four spikes to each joint.

Studding to be 12 feet long set three feet centres 6 x 6 and securely spiked to piers with 6 inch spikes.

End plates to be 24 ft long 4 x 4 securely spiked to studding, side plates to be 24 ft long 6 x 6 and attached to studding in like manner.

Ten trimmers 24 feet long 6 x 6 securely spiked to piers and set 10 ft from end with stone pier in centre to support girts for framework of roof with stud 12 feet long 6 x 4 set in centre of trimmer with cross girts 24 feet long 6 x 4 spiked to piers, studding and at a height of 6 feet with another girt 24 feet long 6 x 6 securely spiked at a height of 12 feet to piers and end studding with holders on plates to properly support the same.

Rafter to be 16 feet long 3 x 5 set 3 feet centres properly hauled on plates and spiked with peak secured with two inch angle bracing spiked to rafters set to be five by six set three feet centre securely spiked to plates and rafters.
