Dear Sir,

While at Whycocomagh Reserve recently, the teacher of the Indian school (Mr. A. MacDonald) brought to my notice the condition of the teacher's residence as a recent storm had torn shingles off a large part of the roof and damaged the remaining part. The rain now comes through the roof and although the teacher made temporary repairs, unless the roof is repaired as soon as possible, the rain will ruin the interior of the building. When I was there, the teacher had cans and other dishes to catch the rain that came through the roof.

The same storm which damaged the roof of the house (as well as many buildings in Whycocomagh) also damaged the roof of the barn. In each case, it was only one side of each building that was damaged. The roof of the barn is beyond repairing as far as shingles is concerned and I would strongly recommend that it, although the building is not now used by the teacher, be also reshingled. I have made a rough estimate of the cost and consider that about $100.00 is required to reshingle the roofs, purchase the required nails and pay for labour.

Shingles can be procured by having the Indians get logs and have them sawn into shingles by William Young who has a sawmill on the Reserve, so that in this manner the funds would mostly remain with the Indians. I strongly recommend that, for the sake of the buildings, this be authorized as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

A. C. MacNeil

Dear Sir,

I am in receipt of your letter 53-2-8, dated May 21st, authorizing shingling of the teacher's residence at the Whyocomagh Indian Day School. The work will be completed in the near future as Indians are employed at it now.

It is noted that the Department is not prepared to pay for reshingling the roof of the barn, especially as it is not now used and recommend that it be torn down and let the Indians who do the work have the lumber for building repairs etc. I have discussed the matter with Mr. MacDonald (the teacher at Whyocomagh) and we considered that it would be a pity to have the building torn down as so much of the material would be unfit for further use. Mr. MacDonald told me that he would make further consideration and yesterday he came to see me and said that Mr. William Young, an Indian who owns a sawmill and lives near the barn says that, if he is given the building for his own use and as his property, he will saw lumber for the Indians (from their own logs) to the amount of $35.00. I consider this a better method as Mr. Young will repair the barn at his own expense and those who require sawing of lumber for their buildings will fare of better then by using the second-hand lumber obtained by tearing the building down. I recommend this.

Re: Teacher's residence, Whyccoomagh Reserve, N.S.

I attach herewith a letter received from William B. Young, an Indian of Whyccoomagh Reserve, N.S., explaining the present condition of the teacher's residence on that reserve and offering to purchase it from the Department.

On receipt of his letter, I asked him what amount he was willing to pay for it and in reply he stated that he was prepared to pay One Hundred Dollars ($100.00) cash.

His statements regarding the condition of the house is correct and while I am of the opinion that his offer of $100.00 is low for the amount of material which is still serviceable, especially on the interior of the building, I feel that this is about all he can afford to pay. The building has not been occupied by a teacher since 1943 and it is quite possible that it will not be used for its original purpose in the future as it is very badly in need of repairs and unsuitable for anyone to live in, in its present condition. If it is the intention of the Department to dispose of this building, as part of the centralization plan, I recommend that Mr. Young's offer be accepted.

F.B. McKinnon, Indian Agent.
I wish to make application again for the teacher's residence here, on the grounds that within another year, it will be a total loss. If in doubt come and see it for yourself. Animals are living in it. This year all the windows are smashed, the ceiling inside smashed and above all the roof is gone. That is, the rain pours in, running inside. The exterior is all right, so there is a chance yet to put it in shape but if left another year it will be a total loss. But I don't want this for nothing; however, I would like to get it at a reasonable price. I find that my house is too small so I have a large family, adding to this, my son has returned from the seminary, I might say they we shall have to sleep in the same room. For the past couple of years teachers have not occupied this house. I trust you will forward to the Dept my request with your strong recommendation.

[Signature]

Your faithfully,

Wm. B. Young.
Ottawa, October 10, 1945.

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT.

Sir,

With reference to the School at Indian Brook, I have to ask for information regarding County Grant or money which became payable at the end of the School year.

The teacher has succeeded in obtaining the half-yearly provincial grant to which he was entitled but to enable him to do so, the Inspector found it necessary to levy the Trustees of the white schools in that vicinity upon the half-yearly returns—there being no board of Trustees for the Indian School.

The Trustees did it in this case to enable the teacher to draw the grant but if it is a necessity it may in future cause trouble as another board of Trustees might not be fit to do so.

You will understand that teachers are entitled to and draw this provincial grant when teaching according to their grade and the school sections have nothing whatever to do with it but with the County Grant it is different, it being a grant paid from the County funds to the Trustees of the different school sections in proportion to the average of attendance made by each school to be used for any school purpose to which the said trustees find necessary to apply it and is of course applied with sectional money to the payment of teachers salaries and other expenses of schools. This paid over by County Treasurers to Trustees on certificate of inspection as to attendance which certificate is I believe made by the Inspector from annual returns signed by the Trustees.

As I have already stated there is no board of Trustees for the Indian School. Therefore no one to sign returns and receive this County grant as provided by law.

Sir,

The Roman Catholic Priest of this Parish, Leo, has been bothering me about the teacher at the Indian School, demanding that he shall teach the Roman Catholic Catechism in the School.

At this the teacher being a Protestant demurs, and on asking my advice I told him first to let the matter pass quietly, but that I did not think under our Provincial School Law that he could legally teach the Catechism.

I believe this view is also held by the Inspector of Schools.

I may say to you that the Priest although he consulted me on other matters in this case has not consulted me at all but assumes to himself the right to interfere with the School and dictates to the Teacher what he shall do this.

Sir,

I hardly know what to say in your communication respecting my dismissal as teacher to the Indians here. You know you had hard work to get a suitable person to take charge of the school; very few caring for such a situation.

I was, I may say, fooled into accepting it, thinking it might be a permanent job. Being a man of family having a wife and six children to support, I hoped to keep the place a few years; accordingly I brought my family and household stuff over forty miles at a considerable expense, as you know, hired a house and settled down to work; now, because I am a Protestant, up it all goes.

I have been on good terms with both the Indians and their priest and I never attempted to instil any Protestant ideas, whatever I may have said I was sure was not contrary to the R. Catholic creed and in accordance with moral morality.

I hope, therefore, that you may influence the Department to reconsider the matter and unless there may be very strong objection by the R. Priest or Indians I may be instructed to resume work again soon.

Yours truly,

Robert J. Logan

Sir,

I have had some trouble lately in connection with one Indian at the reservation in connection with the school; and as it has not been the first or second time, I thought it proper to seek the Department for advice with regard to him.

The fellow's name is Stephen Maloney. He lives close to the school and has sent two boys, Frank and Stephen, pretty regularly to the school and they have done quite well.

Old Stephen, as you know, was once chief over a year ago, but the most of those on the reserve do not accept him as such, and called for another election; this makes Stephen very bitter and jealous, thinking he threatens to shoot others who don't like him.
One day I called his boy Frank back to his seat for not leaving the room in a proper manner and he kept him and the other one home for a time and sent some others off home who were coming to the school. Another time he came over to the school house before school time because he thought that Mr. Donald's school was complaining about his boys fighting. This time nothing and getting along altogether disagreeable. Frank makes the trouble he learns well and I could manage him easily but the old Red won't be reasonable. Frank wants to fight whenever he can make it out whenever he can get a weaker one to put upon. He has been fighting and carrying on a good deal lately and some were keeping children home. One girl has been kept home nearly the whole winter on account of Frank as I have been told. This girl told at home that Frank was acting unusually with another little girl at the school; this I can scarcely believe as I was present most of the time when they were attacked and the little ones as well as the older ones can tell or state the truth.

However, one day lately I observed Frank imposing on young Mr. Donald and I called him in, took him by the collar, slightly shook him, and told him he must keep quiet charging him to leave Mr. Donald's house going home. I am going to ask a favour of you; and I think—and I hope—you may not think it altogether undeserved.

What I am going to ask you is to make my little salary three hundred dollars a year after the 30th June next. If you will grant me this, I promise you I will not again ask an increase while you are pleased to retain me in your service as teacher in an Indian school.

Deputy Superintendent General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

You would like to see a better attendance at the day school here. I would also like it, but I am afraid we shall be disappointed, if we expect a much better attendance this summer.

There are, we may say, six families on this reserve now; but before the end of the present week, there may not be that many.

There are eight children of school age in the place at present. Five of these are pretty well grown, over twelve and up to fifteen years. The old ones find these big ones useful to run and beg milk or gather mayflowers to sell.

I walk around among them and do what I can to get them out and succeed in a measure. They are poor and improvident, the children are very often hungry; in cold weather their clothing and shoes are so poor that they do not protect them from the frost.

This reserve is five miles, or three-fourths from a railway and they do not like to travel over these five miles of dirt—they do not care how far it is in the car—so they incline to get near the Railway and leave this place doubly.

I think the principal thing that keeps them here at all is the church—they have a pretty good one here—
They like to sing and pray; and perhaps it does them good; most likely they would be much more wicked without it.

They would not agree to find the money for the school, and after you granted pray to get that, the young fellows would stay home if I asked them to help at it. Then I took to calling it all myself, merely asking them to carry it in still they don't attend well.

They talk sometimes and say that they ought to have a Catholic to teach them; they had Catholic teachers at Cow Bay near Dartmouth and the school went down for all that. The Indians did not find it a real easy place to live in.

I think it somewhat of a problem to solve; the un-enlightenment, civilizing making farmers and useful citizens of the Micmacs. We will keep on trying, but they will never be as much for use as common, I am afraid.

Perhaps, if you would send John Noel, the chief here, a letter telling him that he must do his best to have the people send their children to school or you would have another man put in his place; it might have a good effect. Tell him that if he worked well in this way so that he would be kept in the chief office a long time. He is as good a man as they can get.

Will you please do this and oblige.

Your humble servant,

Robert J. Logan
Teacher

Dear Sir,

May I ask a favour of you? I have heard you say, "Take away, but we want permission to sell." Will it be this way? I have been teaching somewhere between twenty and thirty years nearly—twelve in White schools and over eight years in this Indian school. I am married, and have been raising a family of six—three girls and three boys—educating them as well as possible under the circumstances, so that one girl is teaching, and the second has a B certificate, hoping to get a C this summer. Two girls and a boy are attending school steadily. My two eldest boys are working at farming. I don't think that I am an old man, but I will be fifty-eight next summer, and no money ahead; could not save any. There are two or three hundred acres of crown land near the reserve, which if I had, I might with the help of my boys make a home, where I could live out my days. The local government granted me 100 acres, now if you would be pleased to grant me 200 acres or even 100 acres as the Lord justifies, I would have enough area for a small farm. It would be easy to arrange with the crown lands office at Halifax about it. They charge 40 cents per acre for such land as this. It has very little wood on it that would make lumber or shingles. Is it practicable? It would repay my heart. Help to follow out. And for you, your petition will be in duty bound, forever grateful.

You most humble and obedient servant,

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Agent Wallace calls the Department's attention to the very unsatisfactory condition of the Shubenacadie school where the attendance has been very irregular for some time and at the date of his report had stopped altogether. The average at this school has been less than 4 for the past two years. About a year ago Chief Noel was asked to use his influence with the members of the Band to induce them to send their children to school. No results seem to have followed this appeal and it is a question whether it would not be better to close the school at the end of the current quarter. It might, however, be given another chance for, say, six months on the condition that if a marked improvement does not take place by the Christmas holidays the school will then be finally closed.

There are about 17 of school age on the Xxxxxxx roll, half of whom are transients, while the census return shows about 20 children who could attend.

For many years before the opening of the school in '94 the Indians were making constant appeals for the education of their children. The Department put up a new schoolhouse at a cost of
$600.00 and their present teacher was appointed on the opening of the school and has been there ever since.

What is wanted here is the enforcement of the Regulations. The Public School Inspector's last report suggests that all children of school age be compelled to attend and says that the teacher is doing as well as he can under the circumstances. I would therefore suggest that the regulations be enforced after the holidays and if this does not have the desired effect that the school be closed at Christmas; and that the teacher and the Indians be so informed.

Sept. 1st, 1905

To the Department of Indian Affairs,

Gentlemen:

You have seen by the return that there is a small attendance at this school for some time. There are only eight families that have now paid the term fees, with seven or eight skeletons of school age attending so irregularly that this is only an average of three more or less.

The Indians here do not take to farming; there is only one who is at all interested in it. They make their living mostly by basket making, handiwork, and sewing. I do not think that the settlement will increase, nor the school be any better.

It was quite unhealthy for a time when there were from a dozen to half a dozen attending, now it is difficult to see five days without a pupil.

They are no better off now, and I am obliged to work when I cannot get pupils in any way they request. We don't want a Catholic to teach our children.

I have been nearly 12 years teaching in this school, and as it is getting so small I thought I would make a proposition to you; let me close the school at the end of the quarter, pay me for the time I have served, and give me expenses, as a kind of pension to help me out. Then after a couple of years if they want the school started again open up again with a Catholic teacher and see if it will be any better. This would ease me down and save the Department a few hundred dollars. What do you say further? You know what is best. I will continue on as I have been doing, if you say so; but I think what I have suggested would be the best for all concerned.

Yours respectfully,

Robert J. Logan
Department of Indian Affairs.

OTTAWA, 18th September, 1905

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Robert J. Logan, teacher of the Shubenacadie Indian school, intimates his willingness to resign if the Department will allow him a year's salary. I may say in connection with this offer on Mr Logan's part that he has been in charge of this school for over ten years and that through no fault of his the school has been going from bad to worse as regards attendance until last year the average had dwindled down to about three. The Agent was written to a couple of years ago and instructed to notify the Indians and the teacher when the school re-opened after the summer holidays that the regulations for compulsory attendance would be enforced and that the Department would hold him responsible for carrying out these instructions. The school is doing no good and should be closed, as it is only wasting money keeping it open. It is for the Department to say whether it will grant Mr Logan any gratuity or not.

Gentlemen:

I thought by the talk of some Indians here at the end of last year that we would have a better attendance during the present half-year; but I was very much mistaken. There seem only eight who could attend but about 3-4 per school day but the greater part of the time we are not there. You said "The school will be closed at the end of the June quarter." It is not worth while running it any longer. Their chief John Noel is one great hindrance to the school. Indians listen to their chief no matter what kind of a fellow he may be; and this old blockhead always talks against the English school. He knows little English himself and can't teach it, and tells the Indians that it is no use to learn it. A number of these Indians now say it would be better to have the Mission teacher, Mission prayers and hymns etc. They are very prone around. Not only the chiefs, the great men, but in a word to encourage them to attend; the fact is, I can do it all myself and so don't trouble yourself. Perhaps if they all would try it might be the same but I think they could help. Anyhow you may expect a very small census for this next.

Is there any other position among the Indians that a man like me might be of use? say looking after their lands, inspecting reserves with regard to sanitation. If you think of anything please let me know.

Gentlemen:

I thank you very much for kindness to me during the time that I have worked in the school here.

Before engaging to teach the Indians, I taught a number of years in the public schools of this province and the local government made me a gift of 100 acres of crown land, on which I have built a house, boarding and shingling it, but have not been able to finish it inside. The lot was covered with wood some of which I have had cut and have started farming.
Phane brought up a family of six—three sons and three daughters; two of them are married (one daughter, the eldest, taught school for a time). Stanley, the second girl, is teaching; the third, 18 yrs., is thinking of it but don't like the idea much. My youngest, Frank, I think would make a scholar if I could only send and keep him to school.

He is 12 yrs. Stanley, my second son has 240 acres of wood land adjoining mine and works mostly at home. I owe $100 to my friend nearly so which I am anxious to pay soon.

We live over a mile from anyone else but we don't feel lonesome. We have a Dominion organ and all the girls can play pretty well.
I am trying farm work and also fishing but not yet tried altogether two or more, not being accustomed to it and not altogether young.

I wrote to the Agent at Eskasoni once about that school, but as he was a friend and they actually Protestant he did not answer.

Is there no place up N.W. where I might train the building kids for a time? Try and give us a job.

Yours respectfully,

Gentlemen:

How would it do to start up the Indian school again? The school building is good and there is some supplies there. There was a week's wood when I left. (They may have stolen the most of it by this time though.)

They might start in better now if we would open up. I would go on for the same salary as I was receiving.

If you do not wish to open this school just now, is there another in the Mar. province that you could appoint me to? Or is there anything else worth while that I could do for you. I would like to work for you again. I have had a slight attack of rheumatism these few days and ought to come...
I want to say a few words about the Indian meadows here.

Although it is not lawful to let cattle run at large here, yet they are let go to make their living on other people's wild meadows sometimes, breaking fences and destroying the crops.

The Indian meadows are eaten down by these cattle every summer until they are hardly worth cutting. Then is built a pound built near these meadows in spring, and if the Indians are told to drive the cattle off the meadows to this pound once or twice I think it would teach the whites a lesson and they would keep them from in future. I wrote the above in confidence you heard about it before but nothing has been done although you wrote to Mr. Wallen to see about it, I think.

Your truly,

R. F. Logan

Sir,

With reference to your letter of the 27th ultimo, No. 120090/1, I beg to report that I visited the Indian settlement at Shubenacadie, N.S., on the 8th inst. and took a census of the children of the place, finding 14 of school going age—that is, between the ages of 5 and 15 years.

Their parents seemed very anxious to have the school in operation again, and I believe that an average attendance of 8 might be confidently expected, if it should be re-opened; because the majority of the children are too young to be otherwise engaged than attending school, and they reside permanently on the reserve. Besides, the school house is centrally located, and is only a short distance from the most remote families in the settlement.

Near the school is a teacher's residence, which is rather small—about 10x14 ft.—and much in need of repairs. I would suggest making a small addition to the back end of it in the form of a lean-to for a bedroom, which with necessary repairs to make the building comfortable, would cost about $65. There are Indians on the Reserve who can do this work.

I would recommend getting the school in readiness and hiring a teacher for the beginning of the Jany. quarter, on the distinct understanding with the Indians that the school should not be kept open for any extended period, in the absence of a satisfactory average attendance.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir,—
As requested in your letter of the 10th ultimo, I beg to advise the Department that Miss Mary E. Ahern began her duties as teacher of the Indian school at Shubenacadie on the 4th inst. I was present at the time, and think that all concerned may be congratulated on having secured the services of a very good teacher. But I'm afraid she will not like the situation, and, therefore, may not be disposed to hold her position for any length of time.

She could not get a boarding house, and, consequently, is obliged to shift for herself as best she can by living alone in the small building near the school provided by the Department for a teacher's residence. In order to encourage her to remain, I promised that the building would be made comfortable, and that she would be provided with free fuel. Under these conditions, she decided to do her best and keep the school, unless the situation should become intolerable.

I engaged Simon Basque, Indian, to furnish the school house and the teacher's residence with

Sir,

I enclose herewith Miss Mary E. Ahern's resignation of her position as teacher of the Indian school at Shubenacadie, N.S.

The statement she thought proper to make with regard to liquor used by the Indians does not give, in my opinion, a proper idea of the facts. Being of a highly nervous temperament, she is easily excited, and was very much disturbed on several occasions at night by the rowdyism of people on the public road, which passes very close to the teacher's residence at Shubenacadie Reserve. She believes that these people were Indians, but I am persuaded they were roistering lumbermen going to and from their camps located a few miles from the Reserve. These experiences seem to have impressed her so seriously, and so unfavourably, that she could not make up her mind to resume charge of the school at Shubenacadie after vacation.

Now, Miss Ahern is a good teacher of large experience, and having reference to the second paragraph of your letter of the 5th inst., I recommend

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
recommend her for appointment as teacher of the Indian school at Sydney. She would live in the city and be among the Indians during school hours only. There would be nothing for her to fear through rowdyism on the part of anyone. Should the Department not think proper to give Miss Ahern this school, I dare say it will not be difficult to find another teacher for it.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.
I am nearly well now and will be ready for work in September.

I take this opportunity of thanking you for your generosity in paying me my full salary. I did not expect it.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

Re: Indian Affairs

I wish to bring to your attention the situation with respect to the Indian day schools in my constituency.

On the Millbrook Reserve the accommodation is most inadequate for the number of children and there are at the present time five or six who are unable to attend school for this reason.

The situation at Shubenacadie is even worse. At that point there are some twenty children of school age and no school facilities. However, the building still stands, but no teacher has been employed for a number of years.

If it is the policy of the Department to give the Indian children some education the Millbrook school should be enlarged and that at Shubenacadie repaired and a teacher employed.

Will you please favour me with your advice in the matter.

Yours sincerely,

(sgd.) G. T. Purdy

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of January 23rd, concerning the letter of G.T. Purdy, Esq., M.P.

We called up Mr. Robb, the Agent, and arranged a time to talk the matter over.

As for the results of the discussion, we feel that Mr. Robb is in favor of opening the day school at the Reserve. He feels this way about it, because the Residential School was established by the Department to take care of orphan children, and these children on the Reserve are not orphans. Again, with a day school there, he feels that they would be satisfied. All of which to me, is, in the first instance not true, and the second is sheer nonsense.

From what we can learn, it appears that Mr. Purdy and Mr. Robb went out to the Reserve. In conversation with Mr. Ben Knockwood, who is known by Mr. Purdy, because, he, Knockwood, worked for Mr. Purdy in the lumber business, the complaint of the Indians was opened. Mr. Purdy went to Mr. Knockwood's house, but Mr. Robb did not accompany him. From that we believe that Mr. Purdy would be voicing the opinion of Ben Knockwood, concerning the school.

As for Mr. Ben Knockwood, he has one boy, between thirteen and fourteen years old, and came to this reserve only a few years ago, certainly at a time when the boy was over school age. Yet we feel that the boy was never at school, even before coming to this reserve. Some years ago we spoke to Mr. Knockwood about the boy coming to the school, but the excuse was that the boy was needed at home to help the mother, and that he was being educated there. There is not much to be said to any Indian when he puts up an argument of that kind.
At the present time we have twelve children from the Reserve, and last week we discharged Henry Knockwood, on the request of the Agent, because the father fell on the ice and was injured, and it was felt that the boy who will be sixteen years of age next August, was wanted at home. The youngest member of the family will probably take his place in September.

We had two of the older girls from the Shubenacadie Reserve, who are here now, make out a list of the children of school age, and the parents of same who are at the Reserve. The total comes to fifteen, the majority of them six, seven, and eight years old. We cannot be certain whether or not this list is absolutely correct.

Looking over the list we think we can say which ones are really opposed to sending their children here, and also the reason.

Martin Sack's two girls -- We had two other girls of this family a few years ago, Jean and Catherine. At the close of the school year, Jean was sixteen years of age, and therefore eligible for discharge. Catherine went home at the same time for vacation. When vacation time was over all the children from that Reserve came back to school except Catherine. You would not remember it but there was quite a time getting her back. Finally she did
arrive back, and later was discharged. Because regulations were followed, the Indian did not like it, and has not forgotten.

Peter Gloade's two children -- a boy, and a girl. We have had three of that family here. One was discharged when she reached sixteen, and the other two did not return from vacation. The mother is all right but we cannot say the same for the father. He was one of the henchmen of a former Agent who gave us a merry time.

Ben Knockwood, mentioned previously, and Stephen Knockwood, we do not know. The others are all young married men, and unless we are very much mistaken, would and will send their children to this school. But as long as we have politicians and the Agent dangling the prospect of a day school at the Reserve, in order to please the older men, then it is only a matter of time until the older men exert their influence on the younger. It is not so many years ago that the ones from this Reserve sent a signed petition to the Department stating that if they would send their children to the Residential School, then we in turn would allow them home every weekend. This letter was sent to the Department with the apparent approval of the Agent at the time.

To our knowledge, Mr. Purdy has been at the Residential School once. And the question at the time was not how much we were trying to do for the Indian, but who should obtain certain work that was contemplated at the time by the Government. If we are not mistaken, it was concerning the tender for painting the outside of the window sashes. We think it would have been the fair thing for Mr. Purdy to learn the other side of the question, why some of the children of the Shubenacadie Reserve are not at the school here.

To get back to our conversation with Mr. Robb, the Agent. Within a month of closing date, we send notice to every Agent who had children here being discharged on July 1st. At the same time we request that if they have any new ones to come in September, to have the application forms filled in soon, and sent
to the Department. We have done the same with Mr. Robb. By the fact that we were told that some of the ones on the Reserve who had been at the school, were no good, we could not help but feel that at least we have not a supporter of the school in the person of the Agent. We are not disappointed in that, because he is entitled to his own opinion, but at the same time, the arguments used, do not, to us, make sense. For if he would think about it, he would know that from among a hundred and sixty children, who are not chosen for their goodness, brains, and ambition, we are bound to have some good, some average, and certainly some bad. No matter how much you try to do with the latter you cannot have much success. Some people expect that we can take any kind of child, and apparently, run him through a mould, and after a few years produce a model that is well nigh perfect. After centuries of civilization, we have not done it with the white man, and it certainly cannot be expected that it could be done with the Indian in a space of a few years.

The parents of the children here come and visit them quite often. We do not claim that they are all satisfied, because we never expect to see any Indian say that he is completely satisfied, but we have no complaints that amount to anything.

Enough of this prattle. If Mr. Robb wants the children of this Reserve to attend the Residential School, all he has to do, as far as we are concerned, is to let us know just about how many we can expect on September 1st, and we will try to have accommodations. But he cannot expect that he can let the matter rest until the first of September, and then call up and expect us to find places for any number of children, for we try to take them in the order that the applications come from the Agents of the three Provinces.

Yours very truly,

DEPUTY MINISTER:

Re - Operation of Indian Day School at Shubenacadie Reserve, Nova Scotia

I wish to reply to Mr. Pratt's memorandum dated January 18, with respect to the re-opening of the Indian Day School at the Shubenacadie Reserve.

In response to instructions sent forward from this Branch, Father Mackey, Principal of the Shubenacadie Residential School, and Mr. J. S. Robb, Indian Agent, met a few days ago and discussed very fully, it would appear, the best ways and means of providing educational facilities for the children of school age on the Shubenacadie reserve. Father Mackey, in his reply to the Department dated January 30, states:

"From the results of this discussion I feel that Mr. Robb is in favour of opening the day school at the reserve. He feels that the residential school was established by the Department to take care of orphan children and that these children on the Shubenacadie reserve are not orphans. Again, with a day school there, he feels that the Indians would be satisfied".

In commenting upon the attitude of the agent, Father Mackey states:

"His first contention is not true and the second is sheer nonsense".

Father Mackey -
Father Mackey concludes:

"If Mr. Robb wants the children of this reserve to attend the residential school, all he has to do as far as we are concerned is to let us know just how many pupils we can expect on September first and we will try to have accommodation. He cannot expect that he can let the matter rest until the first of September and then call up and expect us to find places for the number of children he may care to suggest. We try to take the children in the order that the applications come from the agents of the three Maritime Provinces".

In view of the fact that Mr. C. T. Purdy, M.P., is interested in this matter, it might be well if he could find it convenient to discuss the subject with Father Mackey. The Principal seems to be convinced that there will be accommodation at the residential school for the pupils of the Shubenacadie reserve. While the Agent appears to be in favour of re-opening the day school, it is exceedingly difficult for the Department to take such action, in view of the statement contained in Father Mackey's communication.

Dear Sir:

May I refer to departmental letter to you dated January 28, 1939, in which you were requested to discuss with the Principal of the Shubenacadie Residential School the desirability of opening the day school on the Shubenacadie reserve. We try to take the children in the order that the applications from the agents of the three Maritime Provinces are received".

You can readily appreciate how difficult it would be for the Department to seriously consider the reopening of the Shubenacadie Day School, when the Principal of the Residential School is prepared to provide accommodation for the children at his institution. It has occurred to me that it might be sound policy to provide Indian day school facilities for the pupils of Prince Edward Island, and New Brunswick who may be at the moment enrolled at the residential school and in this way open up accommodation for the children of the Shubenacadie reserve. By adopting this policy we would save the transportation costs of children who come from a distance. In any event I am submitting the Principal's statement to you for any comment or recommendation you may care to forward.

In view of the fact that this matter has been referred to us from the office of the Minister, I should appreciate your dealing with it as promptly as possible.

Yours very truly,

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

Accompanied by Indian Agent Robb I visited the Shubenacadie Indian Reserve on June 4, 1939. The Indians had been advised of my visit by the Agent and I was greeted by practically the entire Band -- men, women and children. As it was a fine day a meeting was held on the lawn outside the church.

The Shubenacadie Reserve consists of 1750 acres. The land appears suitable for farming but only a few of the Indians had cultivated gardens. The Reserve is located between 4 and 5 miles from the village of Shubenacadie. As you know the Shubenacadie residential school is just outside the village.

CHILDREN

At the present time there are 14 children 7 years of age and over on this Reserve who have not yet attended school. In addition there are 8 children who are between 6 and 7. This makes a total of 22 children over 6 years of age.

There are approximately 20 children under 6 years of age.

There are 10 children ranging in age from 8 to 14 who are attending the Shubenacadie Indian residential school.
ARGUMENTS FOR ESTABLISHMENT OF A DAY SCHOOL

Several of the Indian men and women expressed the opinion that a day school should be established. They stated that they wanted to have their children at home. One of the leaders of the discussion was an Indian named Ben Rockwood who has one boy 15 years of age who has never attended any school. I asked him the reason why the boy had never been sent to school and he stated that owing to his wife's ill health he had to keep the boy at home to look after his mother. Many of the Indians stated that they would be prepared to provide clothing for their children if they were attending a day school on the Reserve. Unless conditions materially improve it is difficult to see how they could do this as the Indian Agent informed me that work was extremely scarce and that as a result practically all the Indians living on the Reserve are in receipt of relief at the present time.

In private conversation with some of the Indians following the meeting it was evident that all of them were not in favour of re-opening the day school on the Reserve but they did not so express themselves while the meeting was being held. The six or seven who spoke at the meeting stated that they wanted the day school re-opened.

BUILDING

The day school on this Reserve was closed in 1930. For the past three or four years the building has been used as a residence by an Indian woman. This building is approximately 15 feet wide by 20 feet long. It has a good hardwood floor and the roof appeared to be in good condition. The Indian woman who has been using the building has erected two or three temporary partitions. In the event of this day school being re-opened on the Reserve it would be necessary to tear down these partitions. The interior would probably
have to be painted. There is a small upstairs in this building which has been uncompleted but possibly could be made into a room for the teacher's living quarters. New toilets would have to be erected and new desks would have to be purchased.

CONCLUSIONS

It is extremely difficult for me to decide whether or not a day school should be opened. From the figures given above it appears evident that there are sufficient children for a day school. At the same time to re-open the school would involve considerable immediate expenditure and in addition the Department would likely have to provide clothing and a generous midday meal in view of the fact that the parents are not able to provide these necessities.

Many of the children over 7 years of age who have not yet attended school could have entered the Shubenacadie residential school if the parents had been sufficiently interested to apply for their admission.

The Principal of the Shubenacadie residential school advised me that owing to the discharge of a number of children at the end of June he would be in a position to provide accommodation for the 14 children on the Shubenacadie Reserve who are of school age; namely, over 7 years.

Up to the present the Shubenacadie residential school has had no difficulty in maintaining its full quota of pupils and even if a day school is established on the Shubenacadie Reserve I do not think it will prevent the Shubenacadie residential school from having its full pupilage.

In the event of its being decided to open the day school I recommend that the Agent be directed to have the repairs to the building made by those at present in receipt of relief. This would reduce the expenditure required to put this building into condition to be used as a school.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

My dear Archbishop McNally:

You will be interested to learn that provision has been made, in our departmental appropriations of this year, for the construction of Indian day schools and teachers' residences at the Eskasoni and Shubenacadie Indian reserves.

It is our intention to construct a 4 room school, a residence for the Sisters who will be placed in charge of the classroom work and a residence for the principal on each reserve. We are now in a position to call for tenders for the construction of these buildings, and it is our hope that work will start at an early date.

I am of the opinion that the success of our Indian welfare program in Nova Scotia will depend, to a very large extent, on the courses of study provided at the schools, coupled with a worthwhile adult educational program, organized and carried forward under the direction of the principals. I can see little reason why the social and economic structure on these reserves should not be, in a very basic sense, co-operative. I have in mind groups of adults, organized for the study of social and economic questions. There should be, also, opportunities for co-operative bulk purchasing and the co-operative sale or disposal of farm and handicraft products. This program, if it is to be successful, will require almost constant direction. Progress at the outset is sure to be slow and the tasks involved, somewhat discouraging. I am naturally anxious, therefore, to secure the services of a young priest with a certain amount of training along the lines I have suggested and a man of unusual missionary enthusiasm.

Re Teacher, Ind. Day School, Shubenacadie, N.S.

Doubtlessly you are well aware that both industry and the services have absorbed too many of our teachers. Consequently there are very few available anywhere and none locally. I happened to know of a woman who taught for a number of years in the Bear River Indian Day School and who was at present unemployed. Her name is Miss Agatha McGinty and I have arranged for her to come and look the situation over.

Before contacting this woman I talked the matter over with Rev. Fr. Mackie and for a while we entertained the possibility of securing one of the Sister's of Charity to substitute. Due to the difficulty of transportation during autumn and winter this idea had to be abandoned. An effort was made to find one locally who could perhaps walk or drive to and from work. As there were none available I was forced to look farther afield.

If Miss McGinty will accept the position and if her application is favorably received in your office, there may be some difficulty procuring a boarding house for her. The nearest white family would be almost two miles away and served by a very unsatisfactory road. We have here a small, bungalow type house, nearing completion. At the Doyle farm we have approximately 350 cords of fuel wood cut from the newly purchased Dodd land. This wood is at present being sawed and split into stove and furnace wood and close to two hundred cords of it should be sold. This matter was brought to the attention of Mr. Arnell, Inspector of Indian Agencies and was approved by him. It will be recalled that fire passed through this property necessitating the immediate removal of all scorched wood, regardless of whether it was hard or soft, fuel or logs, as long as it was worth salvaging. Practically everything damaged came out this winter and all logging operations ceased on March 14th. I have hired a local wood-cutting outfit and as soon as possible after the cessation of logging we started to cut up this wood. This was one week from the day we moved out of the woods, the delay being caused by the depth of the snow which covered the greater portion of the wood. Due to the injury to this wood at the time of the fire such a large amount cannot remain piled for eventual use. I suggest keeping only what is necessary for the old and destitute of this and Truro reserve plus next year's requirements of both Day Schools. The balance, as stated previously, should be sold as soon as possible. I think for the good of the community in and around Shubenacadie this wood should be sold to individual buyers rather than to a wood dealer. It will have to be borne in mind that the wood was blackened by the fire and that it is of a mixed variety approximately half hard and half soft. These factors will lower its sale price somewhat but I will get the best possible prices for it and keep within selling prices. I have contacted the W.P.T.B. in Truro re the possibility of procuring the one dollar per cord subsidy paid to wood dealers and if successful will have this to compensate for the lower sale price. I would appreciate having your approval of this proposed sale as it appears to be the practical thing in this case.

We have at the mill approximately four hundred thousand feet of timber. I believe it is a better grade than last year's cut and all but twenty thousand came from the Dodd
land. This will be sawed and were it not for the frost which threw our mill out of line we would be at it now. It is a big cut and I believe it will require almost three months to cut it. We plan to start as soon as possible. I might mention that we have left over from last year about 200 M. f.b.m. in mostly two inch. Should a school be built here this summer there is not likely to be any shortage of lumber. From the Dodd land purchased for five hundred dollars we have taken close to four hundred thousand feet of good Timber, well over four hundred cords of wood and left standing about 50 M of fire-free timber and 250 cords of good wood.

REPORT ON SHUBENACADIE INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH APRIL, 1944.

On March 20th Miss McGinty who had been engaged on this reserve as teacher in the Day School since November 5-43 abruptly resigned due to ill health. She contracted a cold in early winter and its persistence worried her. She feared too the possibility of T.B. contacts and abruptly ceased duties, and asked to be allowed to return to her home. At first I planned to hold her until a replacement could be found but after an interview I sent her home immediately. She appeared to be nervous and slightly hysterical and in that condition was of absolutely no use in a schoolroom. Luckily I had heard from Agent MacLean of Eskasoni of a teacher seeking employment and I wired for her posthaste. She arrived on March 28th and re-opened the school the day following. She is a middle aged woman of experience and undoubted ability and energy. Already she has won the respect of both parents and children. She is firm and on entering the classroom it is quite evident that she has done this work before. She was quite disappointed in her salary cheque for the month of April. I had told her that the bonus would be $18.42 and apparently she had not become accustomed to the drastic income tax deductions. I trust some satisfactory adjustment can be made as I do not favour the prospects of looking for another teacher this time of year. In fact a replacement is practically impossible to obtain and if she leaves the school will have to remain closed for the balance of the term.

Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

Re: New Shubenacadie Reserve

I spent September 8 and 9 with the Indian Agent on this reserve. At the present time there are approximately 300 Indians residing on the reserve. Forty houses have been completed and of these eight were built during the current year. Five more cellars were being dug and this means that five more houses will be completed before the winter. A recent census of the reserve indicated that there are 107 children under the age of sixteen. Of course, all of these are not of school age at the present time. A visit to the day school which we are operating on the reserve until the new building is finished showed the names of 48 pupils on the register. As a result the old day school is extremely crowded and, pending the completion of the new building, it may be necessary to have the younger children come for half a day and the older children for the other half day.

The erection of the new building is proceeding rather slowly. At the time of my visit on September 9 the foundation had been completed and it was hoped that the work would progress more quickly so that the walls would be erected and the roof on before the cold weather started. At the time I visited the reserve the well digger had not yet struck suitable water, although I phoned Mr. Buck today and was informed that suitable water had been secured at a depth of 327 feet.

At the present time we are still operating schools on the Afton Reserve, Indian Cove Reserve and Millbrook Reserve. The Afton Reserve is just outside the town of Antigonish and Indian agent Rice states that very few of the Indians residing here wish to move to the new reserve, as they can obtain work in Antigonish. The Indian Cove School is situated near Pictou Landing and the Millbrook School is located a short distance from Truro. In both cases the Indians are very reluctant to move to the new reserve for the same reason as I stated in regard to the Afton Reserve. I recommend that the Principal's residence and the teachers' residence be erected next year. As soon as the school is finished the other buildings will be required and they should be provided at the earliest possible date.

On September 5 in Halifax I interviewed the Mother Superior of the Sisters of Charity. This is the same Order as we have in the Shubenacadie Residential School. They are willing to provide whatever number of qualified teachers we require. However, they have made all their appointments for the current academic year and, in view of
the delay in erecting the building, it will not be possible for them to provide any Sisters until the academic year 1945-46. I pointed out that in addition to teaching the school it would be expected that the Sisters would take an active interest in home makers' clubs on the reserve. The Mother Superior promised that they would do this and to assist us in this regard they would arrange to send one Sister who has had considerable experience in social service work. As you know, the salaries of teachers have been considerably increased in the white schools in Nova Scotia this year. It was agreed with the Mother Superior that the following salary rate would be suitable: $1200 a year for the principal and $1000 a year for each assistant.

This Order not only provides qualified teachers for schools, but also has a number of Sisters who are qualified nurses. One of their activities is the operation of a big hospital in Halifax. In the event of a nursing station being established on the new Shubenacadie Reserve, I feel very definitely that one of the Sisters should be employed. This would mean that both the teaching services and the nursing services would be in charge of the same Order and would no doubt give us beneficial results.

At the present time, as you are aware, considerable employment is being given to the Indians in the erection of the new houses. I also noted that several had cultivated gardens during the past summer. A separate report is being submitted regarding the lumber which is at present surplus to requirements.

Both the Indian Agent and the clerk seem to be fully conversant with their duties and apparently are working hard to get everything into good shape.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Sirs:

Re: New School.

I would like to get some information regarding teachers for the new school. The school and the continual controversy over teachers has given us all a great big headache.

We better, right now, come to an understanding regarding teachers for the school re. 1945-1946.

I told Mr. Rice this morning I intend to come back to teach here next year.

I was given to understand that you want the "Sisters" to come and teach in the new school. In fact I heard this a million times since I came here last year. May I ask you the reason why?

You know the rule regarding teachers of Indian day schools.

No teacher can be dismissed or discharged if the work in the class-room is satisfactory.

My work since I came here has been more than satisfactory.

You got a wonderful report from Mr. Campbell, the Inspector of Schools, regarding my work, still you had the idea you could bring in Sisters and Indians day teachers for no reason whatever. You can bring them in tomorrow if you wish but you will have to pay me a year's salary. We had so many false reports coming in from your department that we don't know whether we are coming or going.

Fr. Brown told me that the Sisters can't come here to teach until their Convent is built. This is something that has not been explained to you before. It would be impossible for them to board at the Residential School and drive back and forth as the roads are blocked to car traffic and even horse traffic for days at a time. When we came from church last Sunday the taxi left us a mile outside the reserve. The car couldn't get through the mud. We have snow-drifts, flood, mud, etc., here.
Mr. Rice and Father Ross visited me this morning and we talked the whole time over. The Indians want me to stay on here and they would like to have another day teacher, until such time as the convent could be built. They are willing and ready to build a two room cottage for the teacher, the same as mine. That would simplify things for everybody.

I hold B. Diploma, honors for physical culture. Under the "Strathcona Trust" rule, I am to draw government grant every six months when I teach physical culture in any school. Mr. Campbell told me to ask you to send me forms, sign them, and return them to you. He said I couldn't draw any grant until I get registered. I also teach sewing, mending, cooking, etc. I did the work of two teachers since I came in here last year, so I hope your letter, or I should say your answer, will ease our headaches. The school won't be ready for another six months anyway. Could you please tell me when and where are civil service exams held, and I hope you will pardon this lengthy document.

Very sincerely,

(Signed) Mary J. Mac Neil.

Dear Sir:

Since my letter to you on July 21 in which we promised to send, as requested, Sisters to the Indian Reserve, I have visited the Reservation at Shubenacadie to examine conditions there.

The school has class-rooms that are spacious, well-lighted, and airy, and when finally equipped, will have all that is needed for the pupils. Yet, no provision has been made for the teachers' comfort; their noon-day meal must be taken in the school where there is no convenience either for preparing it or for taking it in any privacy. There is no room where the Sisters might keep their outdoor wraps, their school books, etc., and you know the Indian propensity for appropriating things.

There is no running water on the premises. I understand a well has been dug, but the water is unfit for drinking. Since water must be brought from a distance of at least two miles, it will take some time to remedy this inconvenience. No toilet facilities are provided for the teachers; evidently they are expected to use the outdoor toilets provided for the Indian children.

The transportation has its own difficulties. Snow in winter, and mud in the spring, will very likely make the roads impassible at times, and always in winter there would be the danger of being storm-stayed at the Reserve.

You will, I believe, recognize the situation as a serious problem for us. We do not wish to go back on our promise to you, but all things considered, it does not seem advisable for us to take over the school until the teachers' residence is ready.

Mr. Rice, with whom I talked over the matter, understands these difficulties. He tells me there is an Indian woman on the Reserve, a former pupil of the residential school, who has written Provincial examinations and attended Normal School. This woman would, he says, be willing to look after the children during the coming year.

I shall appreciate it very much if you will let me hear from you very soon if some arrangement can be made for the year 1945-1946 which will not necessitate our sending the Sisters yet.

Dear General Chisholm:

There are positions for nurses vacant in all these institutions.

The Indian Affairs Branch also has a field nursing staff of about fifteen nurses, and in the next year or so will require at least 70.

Our basic salary is $80 a month, plus cost of living bonus which is at present $18.42, plus full maintenance. Nurses with adequate training in Public Health are offered $1260 per annum, plus cost of living bonus, plus full maintenance. Matron's salaries are in accordance with Civil Service classifications.

Indian Reserve School—Shown above is the new school on the Indian reserve at Shubenacadie. Opened last fall, the school has four classrooms, Domestic Science, Sewing, vocational training and cooking rooms. About 165 pupils attend the school. Major D. A. MacDonald was the contractor.
With regard to the new School, which is finally completed, excepting installation of registers for the floors and these have not arrived from the manufacturers as yet. This has been a long drawn out process—about fifteen months constructing the building. I feel however that MacDonald, the Contractor, has done a real good job and that nothing has been slighted in any way. We certainly have a nice building and it is a great credit to the Reserve. Throughout the job, most of the work was done by two men and Indians from the Reserve supplied the remainder of the help. This building will require a lot of attention, both inside and outside and I attend to burn wood in the furnace for this year, as there is plenty on hand, with only two classrooms to be heated. I have recommended Joseph Rose, the only competent Indian I have, for the job. He lives near the School and I have recommended his salary at the rate of $50.00 per month. Although this might seem rather high, yet the building will require someone to look after it day and night and considering circumstances, I do not think this rate to be unreasonable. I am waiting Departmental instruction on this matter. As I had to hire two teachers at the beginning of the school term, expecting that the new building would be ready, it has been necessary to have two sessions each day in the old school, one in the morning for the higher grades and another in the afternoon for the lower grades. Because there was not room in the old school, this has been necessary. Immediately the seats, desks and chairs arrive I intend to open two rooms of the new school as this will be sufficient for this year and will be as far for heat. Mr Rose of the Engineering Service was here for two weeks, surveying out the water line from the Spring Brook to the Reserve. He found abundance of water and an analysis showed it to be in first class condition. He also inspected the new School and found it to his entire satisfaction. While construction of the building since last Christmas, has taken up quite a lot of my time, due to the fact that there was no Engineer here, Mr Rose' favourable comments made me feel that time I had spent on it had been well worthwhile.

H.C. Rice,
Indian Agent.
There was considerable uncertainty at the beginning of the school term with regard to the hiring of teachers. It was generally understood that the Sisters would be taking over at the new School on the Reserve here. With this in mind, I intended to have Mrs. MacNeil, who had taught last year on this Reserve, placed as teacher at Millbrook. However when it became known that the Sisters would not be able to take over the new School, I was advised by the Department to retain Mrs. MacNeil and in addition, to if possible, obtain the services of another teacher. I was able to engage Mrs. Elsie Basque to teach with Mrs. MacNeil on the Reserve here, but it meant there was no teacher at Millbrook. After advertising in the papers, the result was I received six or seven applications and from these I selected one who seemed best qualified, Miss Mary B. Cameron, who is, I feel doing a very good job and I am quite satisfied with her work.

H.C. Rice,
Indian Agent.
We finally managed to move into our new School the first of November. Two classrooms only are in use and these have been kept warm quite easily by burning wood. Because the remainder of the School has been closed off, it has been possible to heat the two rooms fairly easily. However I feel sure that when the time arrives and we have four teachers, we will have to use coal for a few months in place of wood. I had some gravel spread around on the School grounds, but there is still considerable work to be done in order to make the playgrounds attractive. In the Spring I will endeavour to get some crushed rock which will make it much drier and should show a much greater improvement. The children are all watched carefully regarding their school attendance and in case of absentees, the Constable is notified and a full explanation is required from the parents. We had Mr. Ross from the Survey and Engineering Branch, checking on the new School and surveying out the proposed waterline.

H.C. Rice,
Indian Agent.

Dear Father Boudreau:

On my recent visit to Shubenacadie I was pleased to note that the buildings we have provided for educational purposes appear to be satisfactory and should make it possible for a complete programme to be carried out for the welfare and progress of Indian children. It now depends upon the personnel to put forth their very best efforts. I feel certain that you will co-operate with me along the following lines:

(a) You should be on the Reserve every day when the school is in operation during the academic year.

(b) You should consult the teaching Sisters each school day with a view to assisting them in any manner that will promote the efficiency of the work and especially in cases of enforcing discipline among the boys.

(c) Establish organized play among the boys by promoting athletic events suitable to the season of the year. In this regard I may say that the Department is prepared to supply reasonable quantities of footballs, basketballs, volley ball equipment, playground balls, and playground bats. It is very important that Indian children should be taught the value of organized play. Physical exercises should be encouraged and every possible endeavour made to promote good sportsmanship in the playing of games. It is understood, of course, that you will supervise all athletic activities.
(d) Debates and concerts should also be organized, especially during the winter months.

A special monthly report form has been prepared and the necessary copies of this form have been forwarded to Indian Agent Rice to whom a copy of this letter is also being sent.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

MODERN INDIAN SCHOOL AT SHUBIE; TRIBAL TRADITIONS PRESERVED

Better homes, better religious and school facilities and a general improvement in health are profits reaped by Micmac Indian population of Nova Scotia mainland from inauguration several years ago of a centralization plan by the Indian Affairs Branch of the Department of Mines and Resources.

The scheme, designed to improve living standards of the Micmac population in the province, is based on establishment of two reservations, one on the mainland and one on Cape Breton Island, and discontinue the system of over 20 reservations scattered throughout Nova Scotia.

Prior to the centralization plan, each reservation was served by a part-time agent, medical care was far from what it should be, school facilities were mediocre and living standards failed to reach the highest standard possible.

Under centralization, each of the two large reservations will have a full-time agent, a resident nurse, better homes and education possibilities and in a short time, a resident doctor.

New School

At Shubenacadie, where the mainland reservation is located, many new homes, some equipped with electricity and running water, have been erected. Influx of Micmacs continued steadily and made better teaching facilities necessary and as a result a modern four-room school was erected, with space for a manual training department. New roads were built and the land cleared, and after a saw mill had been erected, logs were sawn into lumber and shingles. At present there is no provision for a high school, but students who wish higher education will be assisted by the Indian Affairs Department.

The attendant nurse is Miss Hazel McDonald, R.N. Housed in the same building containing the agent's office and the medical room is a fully equipped community store. Here handicrafts for which Micmacs are famous, can be exchanged for every-day necessities.

Following tradition, Shubenacadie is governed by a chief, with Steve Knockwood, re-elected for the second time, at present occupying this important post. Councillors associated with him are Simon Nevens, John Francis, Charles W. Francis and Henry Sack.

Five years ago when centralization started the population at Shubenacadie was approximately 50 people. Today it numbers about 550.

Re: Food records of day school pupils

Dear Mr. Rice:

As previously discussed, we will hold a clinic on Thursday, April 7th, on the older grades of children at the Day School on the Reserve. In addition to this medical-dental clinic, it is essential to get some idea of the food pattern of these children and this can best be done with the aid of the teachers and the nurse by the nutritionists from here who will visit at a separate time from the medical clinic.

Therefore I propose that two of our research nutritionists should visit the Day School for a period of about ten days for the purpose of obtaining a week's diet record beginning after the Easter holidays. Miss Suzanne Saint Hilaire will be in charge because she has already been at the Residential School and, I guess, has seen the Day School. She will be assisted by Miss Dorothea Tripp. They will plan to arrive on Sunday, April 24th, or Monday, the 25th and will let you know directly of any assistance required in this regard.

The chief purpose for writing you at this time is to point out the great advantage to these girls if they could live on the Reserve. Naturally, they would be glad to pay for their lodging and to fit into what accommodation was available. Would you please inquire from the teachers or from the nurse whether this can be arranged and advise me at your convenience.

Looking forward to seeing you shortly, I am,

Yours sincerely,

L. B. Pett, Ph.D., M.D.,
Chief, Nutrition Division.

Memorandum:

SUPERINTENDENT OF INDIAN EDUCATION

Re: Schubenacadie Indian Day School

The enrolment of this school is 124. There is quite a bit of room left for expansion which does not promise to be very rapid. There is a good Domestic Science room and a handy Manual Training shop. Mr. Brown, the manual training instructor met me at the school. With the principal, the agent, Mr. Brown and myself discussed the proposed set-up. I believe Mr. Brown understands the Department's aims in manual training. Mechanical tools are not desirable for the present. Our pupils are too young yet to handle such machines. It would be advantageous, however, to have a grindstone and a variety saw to help the teacher prepare the material for instruction. A complete set of hand tools will be necessary for both the Day School and the Residential School, as neither of them have any woodworking equipment. A requisition has been submitted and after some changes will be submitted for approval.

It was interesting to note that the Day School pupils participated in the Music Festival that took place at Schubenacadie and according to reports have figured advantageously.

Respectfully submitted,

A. J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Vocational Education.

Shubenacadie, N.S.
Oct. 20th 1913.

Dear Sir,

I received a check from the Dominion Department for $42, in payment for 21 school days. The total number of school days in the quarter are 66, which I must have omitted in my quarterly returns, and 45 of these are authorized holidays, being the summer vacation, as the school does not actually open until Sept 2nd. The number of actual days taught are 21, no school was held until Sept 2nd, Sept 1st being Labour Day, which is a Public Holiday.

My salary is $400 per year, and I understand that I would receive $100 for the first quarter. If there is
and necessary I will gladly make them out a second time. The number of the check which I received is 1573, the date Oct 18th, and the amount $42. Trusting that you will make satisfactory explanations.

Yours Truly,

Mary A. Smith
Ottawa, October 24, 1913.

Madam,-

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant with reference to the amount of salary received by you as teacher of the Shubenacadie Indian Day School for the quarter ended September 30th, last.

As you are a new teacher at this school, having commenced duties after the summer holidays, payment of salary for the September quarter was allowed only for the number of days which you had school open, twenty-one. I enclose a copy of the Indian Day School Regulations, which will inform you of the method adopted by the Department in the payment of teachers' salaries. There are two hundred teaching days in the year and if you remain in the service of the Department and teach that number of days to June 30th, next, you will receive your full yearly salary, $400.00.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Assistant Secretary.

Miss Mary A. Shortt,
Teacher,
Shubenacadie Indian School,
Shubenacadie, N.S.

October 6th

Sir,

I reply to your letter of the 26 ultimo, I have the respect that you will inform me of what size the proposed school house should be and also an estimate of the cost of completing the same with full details.

I also desire to enquire whether logs could not be obtained from the Reserve for the walls of the proposed building and the labor of the Indians in getting out and flattening the same estimated.

A very neat building might be erected of logs properly flattened & afterwards painted which would probably be paid for at less than one third the cost much less than a frame building.
Respected Sir,

In reference to a School Building for the Indians I have say that I have asked a Builder what he thought about the matter. Asked him to make an estimate of the cost of a Frame building which the Indians would follow. A Frame Building Boarded Chingled with 6 Windows 1 Door 1 Chimney 16 Seats 1 Desk and painted outside the probable Cost of which would be about $275. The Indians think they can not get out the Log so that they would be fit to paint or finish but they say they would get out the frame of the building where would make the Frame building Cost $24. They said the Builders says the Frame building would cost less when finished than Log one and the Indians had very poor frame I think it would last them too much to put a Log one and they say would do without having it finished inside for a time.

Yours etc.
James G. Eg
Bureau Agent

Specifications for a School House to be erected at Indian Brook, Shubenacadie in the County of Annapolis and Province of Nova Scotia

The building to be 25 x 18 feet outside with two feet posts to rest on the large hemlock tree. Six feet 6½ feet in the ground, and to stand one foot above the surface at the highest place, the posts to be placed from the bottom of the cellar to the ground and then fastened to the building all around.

The walls to be put together with mortise and tenon and properly fastened to have joints 9½ inches placed in the walls at two feet centres properly joined in the upper beams to be framed on the plates and to be sixteen inches from centre to centre.

The rafters to be 15 feet long 6x2 inches and placed 2 feet apart, and cut for the projection of hanging ears and project one foot from the side wall and well fitted to the plate the plates to be 3 inches in thickness. The eaves and gables to be finished with a plain and neat finish.

The walls and roof to be well though boarded with good spruce or hemlock boards on such as the knees must be sheathed with No. 1 Hemlock Shingles laid 1¼ inches to the weather. To be finished with saddleback. The roof to receive one good coat of metallic lead paint. The walls to be covered with No. 1 Sawn Spruce Shingles laid 5 inches to the weather and when finished to get two good coats of lead paint well mixed with linseed oil and properly put on.

The building to have seven windows and frames placed as directed by the Indian agent. Manufactured by good men properly made to be capped and zinced put neatly on the caps. Sashes to be 1½ inches and made to hang from the bottom to have 8 lights of
12 x 14 inch glases, or 12 lights or 9 x 12 glass as the contractor may prefer, well glazed after being primed. Sashes to be drawn in India Red paint after being glazed.

To have two panel doors placed as directed by the Indian agent. To be properly furnished with hinges and locks of good quality and well capped and glue put neatly on the edges.

To have a double floor laid, the lower floor to be of good Spruce or Hemlock boards of even thickness. The upper floor to be of good Spruce boards planed and well seasoned.

The whole of the inside to be well plastered with well burnt lime. The mortar to be well mixed with hair and fresh sharp sand to be furnished with one coat of plaster to be furnished with base boards painted wide all around inside of building.

The whole of the inside to be sheathed with matched Spruce boards, not more than 6 inches in width, well seasoned, and to receive one good coat of paint of some dark colour.

(Parties tendering will offer for either way)

To have a good six inch flue from the chimney to stand three feet above saddle boards set on three planks on top of beams with two or more solid courses of brick in the bottom, with pipe safe inside flue band, plaster box in ceiling to admit stove pipe being fitted into flue.

The flues to be suspended from the roof to support the flue.

All inside woodwork (whether building be plastered or sheathed) to have one good coat of paint of a colour to be named by the Indian agent at Chilcotin.

Dear Sir -

Am in receipt of your letter of 21st inst., complaining of amount of bill for building fire; hauling brick, sand, lime, cement, etc.

Noel MacDonald was one day hauling brick, about 7 miles.

Simon Bourque one day hauling sand about 6 miles and another day getting lime and cement and taking communication to you.

Kean Sack, two and a half days helping to clean up schoolhouse, carrying water, and keeping fire in stove to heat water for the master.

I might say that the fire was small, but it required just as much time to get the materials as it would for a much larger one.

My charges were $5 to get a man, so Bourque did not wish to build the fire;
but I was unable to get any, so no one wished to work in the cold. Also, for getting the Indians to clean the school house. I was in reality four days, but only charged for two, as I thought the bill quite large enough.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., enclosing labour bill amounting to $20.80, for taking down the old flue in the Indian school house at Shubenacadie and building a new one.

The expenditure incurred is a surprise to me, and, I think, excessive. At any rate, before paying the bill, the Department will certainly require an explanation as to why it was necessary to employ a man and team three days in the work of building a flue requiring only 350 bricks. Again, Thomas McDonald took down the old flue, and Simon Basque built the new one, with Henry Sack as his assistant, carrying bricks and mortar. What was Isaac Sack doing during the 2½ days he was employed? Kindly explain.

I presume your own charge in the matter was for the time occupied in coming to Shubenacadie to communicate by wire, and afterwards, in purchasing materials for the flue.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

The Indian School house at Shubenacadie is badly in need of repairs. I understand that Mr. Superintendent Boyd made certain recommendations regarding this past year but there was nothing done. I consider the following as being absolutely necessary and should be done before the school re-opens in September. The inside of the building refinished, as it is now it is very cold. A wood house is badly needed as at present the wood gets wet as there is no shelter. A closet is required in the School to keep books, papers etc. in. A new Blackboard is urgently needed also a large Globe and map of the Dominion. The seats are in a disgraceful condition and new ones will have to be provided.
