By request of your agent here I have visited the Indian day School and personally inspected same and estimated cost of repairs as contained in your specification and I estimate that what you specify will cost $210.00.

I find that this building is sitting on a wood foundation which has rotted away and allowed the building to settle out of shape and break the plaster. I would recommend that the building be straightened into shape and a concrete wall 2 ft in height 8 inches at bottom and 1 inch at top be built under building also 3 Piers under center of building. This would do away with the wavering of building. The ceiling is of wood and is full of knot holes and very much shrinken. I would recommend that this be covered with Beaver Board and painted. The plastering runs down to the floor without any base board for protection and is considerable broken.
I would recommend that school room be varnished to bottom of windows about 3 ft in height. A new floor is also required as the old one is worn through and would have to be replaced in at least another year. I have estimated the cost of repairs contained in your specification at $210.00.

Sir,-

Referring to your letter of June 7th., I beg to report that I inspected the school house at Shubenacadie reserve in July, and found, as Mr. Inspector Campbell stated, that the plaster on the walls of the school room had begun to crack and shell.

I do not advise using plaster again instead of Beaver Board, as I believe the latter to be less expensive and more lasting.

My dear Mr. Lawlor:

On the occasion of my visit to the Indian Reserve near Shubenacadie, I found the water supply most unsatisfactory. The water which I saw was very bad, some times fills me, that after heavy rains, it cannot be used for drinking purposes.

Last summer the Dept. authorized the agent for Cumberland Reserve to have a well sunk for the purpose of supplying good water on this Reserve. A similar well, with a pump, would be one way of remedying condition on Indian Brook Reserve.

The school also should be supplied with a tank or some such container for water. Individual cups are also a necessity, particularly where there are prospect cases of tuberculosis. Mrs. King would be willing to see that the children brush their teeth, if they are supplied with toothbrushes.

Yours very truly,

Brook Village  
Inverness Co.  
N.S.
Sir,

Enclosed please find a letter from Miss C. T. McDonald, R. N., in which she advises me that she has found the water supply at the Indian Reserve unsatisfactory and recommends that a well be supplied to remedy this. Also that the school be supplied with a water tank and individual drinking cups, also tooth-brushes be furnished the children.

I would say that I can procure a tank for $6.00. Drinking mugs from 20¢ to 25¢. Tooth brushes from 35¢ to 50¢.

In reference to the water supply would say that the following families, the Glodas, Mrs. Williams, Mrs. Rubs Paul, Simon Faqque, Mrs. King and the school get their water from a brook or a hole dug in a swamp. In summer the swamp dries up, also the water in the brook gets very low and at such time it is not very good for drinking purposes. Again after big rains when the brook is flooded, the water is muddy and unfit for use. During the winter months this brook which is away below the level of the road makes it very difficult, on account of ice conditions, for the people to carry the water from same.

I would fully recommend that the well be dug near the school house with a pump attached to same as I think this quite necessary. I cannot give you an estimate of what this work would cost as I do not know how far one would have to sink to get the water. Just roughly, I think they would probably get water at a distance of 20 or 25 feet.

If the above request meets with your approval, kindly send me the necessary authority and I will have the articles asked for for the school procured as soon as possible and the well dug at the first convenient opportunity and think I can get Indian labor for the work.

Your obedient servant,

D. B. Fowler

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Shubenacadie Indian Day School, recommends that a new stove be supplied, and also that a supply of dry wood be delivered and piled in the woodshed in the summer. He states that the present stove is useless, and the wood not as good as it should be. He also states that, on the day he visited the school, the teacher was not able to keep the children warm in the schoolroom, and took them into her own dwelling, where the school work was conducted.

If you consider that a new stove is required, you may arrange for the purchase of same. You should obtain a stove of a type suitable to properly heat the building. Please obtain competitive prices, if possible, from a number of dealers, and make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. Should any stove pipe be required, you may also arrange for the purchase of same. If you make this purchase, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. While a serviceable stove should be obtained, it should be purchased as cheaply as possible.

Relative to the wood, it is noted that ten cords of hardwood were supplied in January, last, and stored in the woodshed. Please state whether you consider this quantity is sufficient to complete the present winter's requirements, and if any further supply would be required for next winter's use, and, if so, when you would recommend that the same be obtained. I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the matter of having a sufficient quantity of dry wood on hand for the balance of this winter and for next winter's use. You should also state what action you have taken regarding the purchase of a stove.

Your obedient servant,

I am taking it upon myself to write you to see if there cannot be something done in the way of putting up a shed that would do for a cow and horse. Ever since I came here (1923) I have been paying out for first one stable and then another only to move at the owner's pleasure. Now the last one I had rented has been sold and the owner wants the building. You may imagine how pleasant it is to go on in this way.

Now I cannot afford to put up
a shed too do I want to sell my house and car. We do without either of them would be very hard in a place like this. Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 26 ultimo, I have the honor to inform you that you will be informed of what size the proposed school house should be and give an estimate of the cost of completing the same with full details.

I have also to inquire whether logs could not be obtained from the Reserve for the walls of the proposed building and the labor of the Indians in getting out and flatter the same utilized.

A very neat building might be erected of logs properly flattened and afterwards painted which would be less than half the cost of a frame building.
Respected Sir,

In reference to a School Building for the Indians I have say that I have asked a Builder what he thought about the matter. Asked him to make an Estimate of the Cost of a Frame Building which the Job was followed by a Frame Building Boarded Chingled with 6 Windows 1 Door 1 Chimney 16 Seats 1 Desk and painted outside the probable Cost of which would be about £275.

The Indians think they cannot get out the Log so that they would be fit to Count or much but they say they would get out the frame of the building where would make the frame building cost £4 less and the Builder says the frame building would cost less when finished than log one and the Indians have very poor Game I think it would not be much to put a Log one and they say would do without having it finished inside for a time.

Specifications for a School House to be erected at Indian Brook, Shubenacadie in the County of Annapolis and Province of Nova Scotia

The building to be 25 x 18 feet outside width twelve feet depth to rest on the large hewlock rock sunk 3½ feet in the ground, and to stand one foot above the sea level at the highest place, the walls to be placed from the bottom of the cellar to the ground and shingled with the building all around.

The walls to be put together with mortise and tenon and properly fastened to have joints 9½ inches placed in the sill, at two feet centres properly joined in the upper beams to be framed on the plates and to be sixteen inches from centre to centre.

The rafters to be 15 feet long 6 x 2 inches and placed 2 feet apart, and cut for the projection of hanging ears and project one foot from the side wall and well spiked to the plate the plates to be 3 inches in thickness. The eaves and gables to be finished with a plain and neat finish.

The walls and roof to be well though boarded with good spruce or hewlock boards one inch in thickness. Roof to be shingled with No. 1 hewlock shingles laid 1¼ inches to the weather. To be finished with saddlebags. The roof to receive one good coat of metallic roof paint. The walls to be covered with No. 1 sawn spruce shingles laid 5 inches to the weather and when finished to get two good coats of lead paint well mixed with linseed oil and properly put on.

The building to have seven windows and frames placed as directed by the Indian Agent. Manufactured by good pure properly made to be capped and zinc put neatly on the caps. Sashes to be 1½ inches and made to hang from the bottom to have 8 lights of
12 x 14 inch glass, or 12 lights or 9 x 12 floor as the contractor may prefer, well glazed after being primed. Sashes to be drawn in India Red paint after being glazed.

To have two panel doors placed as directed by the Indian agent, to be properly furnished with hinges and locks of good quality and well capped and gusseted neatly on the caps.

To have a double floor laid, the lower floor to be of good spruce or hemlock boards of even thicknesses. The upper floor to be of good spruce boards placed and well seasoned.

The whole of the inside to be well plastered with well burnt lime. The mortar to be well mixed with hair and fresh sharp sand to be furnished with one coat of plaster to be furnished with base boards finished wide all around inside of building.

The whole of the inside to be sheathed with matched spruce boards not more than 6 inches in width well seasoned, and to receive one good coat of paint of some dark colour.

(Parties tendering will offer for either way)

To have a good air brick flue from the chimney to stand three above saddle boards set on 3 inch planks on top of beams with two or more solid courses of brick in the bottom with pipe safe inside flue and plaster box in ceiling to admit of stove pipe being put into flue. Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 16th inst., enclosing labour bill amounting to $20.20, for taking down the old flue in the Indian school house at Shubenacadie and building a new one.

The expenditure incurred is a surprise to me, and, I think, excessive. At any rate, before paying the bill, the Department will certainly require an explanation as to why it was necessary to employ a man and team three days in the work of building a flue requiring only 350 bricks. Again, Thomas McDonald took down the old flue, and Simon Basque built the new one, with Henry Sack as his assistant, carrying bricks and mortar. What was Isaac Sack doing during the 2½ days he was employed? Kindly explain.

I presume your own charge in the matter was for the time occupied in coming to Shubenacadie to communicate by wire, and afterwards, in purchasing materials for the flue.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Superintendent.

Sir,

The Indian School house at Shubenacadie is badly in need of repairs. I understand that Mr. Superintendent Beyd made certain recommendations regarding this past year but there was nothing done. I consider the following as being absolutely necessary and should be done before the school re-opens in September. The inside of the building refinished, as it is now it is very cold. The building should be shingled; this has not been done since it was built 21 years ago. The building has never been painted and should be painted inside and out. A wood house is badly needed as at present the wood gets wet as there is no shelter. A closet is required in the School to keep books, papers etc.

A new Blackboard is urgently needed also a large Globe and map of the Dominion. The seats are in a disgraceful condition and new ones will have to be provided. I would suggest having a carpenter go over the building and report just what is necessary.

Your obedient servant,

W. G. Foote

Sir,

My dear Mr. Lawlor:

On the occasion of my visit to the Indian Reserve near Shubenacadie, I found the water supply most unsatisfactory. The water which I saw was very bad, and Mr. King tells me that after heavy rains it cannot be used for drinking purposes.

Last summer the Dept. authorized the digging for a well on the Reserve, but a well sunk for the purpose of supplying water on this Reserve—a similar well with a pump—would be one way of remedying conditions on Indian Brook Reserve.

The school also should be supplied with a tank or some such container for water. Individual cups are also a necessity, particularly where there are suspected cases of tuberculosis.

Mr. King would be willing to see that the children brush their teeth, if they are supplied with toothbrushes.

Yours very truly,

Brook Village  
Inverness Co.

Sir,

Enclosed please find a letter from Miss C. T. McDonald, R. N., in which she advises me that she has found the water supply at the Indian Reserve unsatisfactory and recommends that a well be supplied to remedy this. Also that the school be supplied with a water tank and individual drinking cups, also tooth-brushes be furnished the children.

I would say that I can procure a tank for $6.00. Drinking mugs from 20¢ to 25¢. Tooth brushes from 35¢ to 50¢.

In reference to the water supply would say that the following families, the Glodes, Mrs. Williams, Mrs. Rubs Paul, Simon Paque, Mrs. King and the school get their water from a brook or a hole dug in a swamp. In summer the swamp dries up, also the water in the brook gets very low and at such time it is not very good for drinking purposes. Again after big rains when the brook is flooded, the water is muddy and unfit for use. During the winter months this brook which is away below the level of the road makes it very difficult, on account of ice conditions, for the people to carry the water from same.

I would fully recommend that the well be dug near the school house with a pump attached to same as I think this quite necessary. I cannot give you an estimate of what this work would cost as I do not know how far one would have to sink to get the water. Just roughly, I think they would probably get water at a distance of 20 or 25 feet.

If the above request meets with your approval, kindly send me the necessary authority and I will have the articles asked for for the school procured as soon as possible and the well dug at the first convenient opportunity and think I can get Indian labor for the work.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Shubenacadie Indian Day School, recommends that a new stove be supplied, and also that a supply of dry wood be delivered and piled in the woodshed in the summer. He states that the present stove is useless, and the wood not as good as it should be. He also states that, on the day he visited the school, the teacher was not able to keep the children warm in the schoolroom, and took them into her own dwelling, where the school work was conducted.

If you consider that a new stove is required, you may arrange for the purchase of same. You should obtain a stove of a type suitable to properly heat the building. Please obtain competitive prices, if possible, from a number of dealers, and make the purchase from the firm quoting the lowest price. Should any stove pipe be required, you may also arrange for the purchase of same. If you make this purchase, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred. While a serviceable stove should be obtained, it should be purchased as cheaply as possible.

Relative to the wood, it is noted that ten cords of hardwood were supplied in January, last, and stored in the woodshed. Please state whether you consider this quantity is sufficient to complete the present winter's requirements, and if any further supply would be required for next winter's use, and, if so, when you would recommend that the same be obtained. I shall be pleased to hear from you regarding the matter of having a sufficient quantity of dry wood on hand for the balance of this winter and for next winter's use. You should also state what action you have taken regarding the purchase of a stove.

Your obedient servant,

I am taking it upon myself to write you to see if there cannot be something done in the way of putting up a shed that would do for a cow and horse. Ever since I came here (1923) I have been paying rent for first one stable and then another only to move at the owner's pleasure. Now the last one I had rented has been sold and the owner wants the building. You may imagine how pleasant it is to go on in this way.

Now I cannot afford to put up
a shed nor do I want to sell my horse and cow. If I do neither of either of them would be very hard in a place like this. As I have every intention of remaining here for a time yet (unless the Sunfish happens), I am writing you to see what can be done. I don't want a large building. I think about 12' x 15', and say 10' high would be fine for cow and horse, and some hay. If the Lord will buy the material, I can have the work done at my own expense.

As I must have my house and cow & hay are stored by March 25th. I hope you will answer as soon as possible.

Thanking you,

Sir:

Replying to your letter March 1st #57-1-5 in reference to the store wood at the Shubenacadie Indian Day School, I found the store in fair condition, with the exception of a small crack in the side, which an expenditure of fifty cents for fire clay will remedy. The pipe has never been abused for some considerable time and needs to be replaced with new pipe and wire. Approx. 12 Lids of Pipe and 3 Elbows and wire for staying pipe in safe condition.

Sir:

Dec. 13, 1932

The Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa Canada

Dear Sirs:

In reply to letter No 51-1-5 of November 24, 1932, Noel Paul moved into the school house on Indian Brook Reserve today (December 13, 1932). The stove he had was not fitted to put, so I was afraid it would burn the building. Therefore I put a stone into the school house. This will be owned by the Department. I had to paid fifteen dollars for it. It was new stove last year, cost at that time twenty-four dollars. Also bought new pipe. These bills are being send under separate cover.

Now it will be safe in case of fire. I couldn't buy stove from Hardware Merchant as he did not have it in stock. But got the pipe from him.

Hoping this satisfactory,

Yours truly,

Allison Macdonald
Indian Agent.

May 8th 1933

The Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa, Canada.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter No 51-1-5 April 25, 1933 regarding teacher's residence at former Shubenacadie Indians' Day School. This house is occupied at the present time by two Indian families.

This is good house, but is badly in need of repairs.

Therefore I have made investigation and found that it will cost about twenty-five dollars $25.00 for repairs.

This includes labor at the rate of $4.00 per hour and material and hardware.

There may be a few other repairs which I did not see; after we tear the shingles off.

Yours Truly,

Allison Macdonald
Indian Agent.
MEMORANDUM:

Regarding correspondence hereunder relative to repairs required to the building formerly used as a teacher's residence at the Shubenacadie Indian Day School, I have to say that, since the opening of the residential school, this building has not been required for school purposes. As it is now occupied by two Indian families, the repairs, as recommended by the Indian Agent, if carried out, should not form a charge against the Appropriation for Indian Education. It is not likely that this building will again be required as a teacher's residence, as the school has been permanently closed. Therefore, any expenditure in connection with the up-keep of the building, while occupied by Indians, should be paid from the Appropriation for Relief.

The Secretary:
I would suggest that Mr. Parker be requested to look into this matter when he visits this Agency.

May 5, 1933

Ottawa, July 8, 1933.

Dear Sir:

It has been decided to re-open the day school on the Shubenacadie reserve. You should, therefore, immediately notify the occupant of the school that she must vacate the building in order that you can arrange for removing the partitions and placing the building in proper condition for a classroom.

When I met you in Shubenacadie, you definitely stated that in the event of the day school being opened the Indians would do the necessary work without cost to the Department.

It will be necessary to erect two new toilets. You should therefore let me know at once what materials are required for these toilets and also what materials will be required for repairing the school.

The Department will depend on you to make this building as habitable as possible.

Arrangements will be made to purchase new desks. You will be notified when they reach Shubenacadie and you should arrange to have them taken to the reserve and placed in the school.

Please give this matter your immediate attention, in order that the school may be opened on September 5.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

J. S. Robb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Shubenacadie, N. S.
